searchDocs.title: Comments
searchDocs.content: Comments A comment in a bash script starts with a sharp symbol (#) and is ignored by the shell interpreter: # test script #1 # Written by Jason Bourne A comment may also be just one portion of a line: cd - # change to the user's previous working directory Note that a shbang line is a comment from the point of view of the shell interpreter -- it's there for the kernel to use, not the shell!

searchDocs.title: Arithmetic
searchDocs.content: Arithmetic Bash can perform integer arithmetic. To evaluate an arithmetic expression and return a value, use $(( )): $Â A=100 $Â B=12 $Â echoÂ $((A*B)) 1200 $Â echoÂ $((B++)) 12 $Â echoÂ $B 13 Note that inside the double-parenthesis, spaces don't matter, and it is not necessary to use a dollar-sign [$] in front of variables being accessed. To evaluate an arithmetic expression without returning a value, use (( )): $Â A=100 $Â B=13 $Â ((A++)) $Â echoÂ $A 101 $Â ((C=A*B*2)) $Â echoÂ "TheÂ answerÂ isÂ $C" TheÂ answerÂ isÂ 2626

searchDocs.content: This script displays a message based on the architecture of the computer:  #!/usr/bin/bashâ€‹ architecture="$(unameÂ -m)"Â #Â unameÂ getsÂ systemÂ informationâ€‹ â€‹ ifÂ `[`"$architecture" == "x86_64"`]("$architecture"_==_"x86_64" "wikilink")`â€‹ thenâ€‹ echoÂ "YourÂ computerÂ architectureÂ isÂ Intel/AMDÂ x86_64."â€‹ elifÂ `[`"$architecture" == "aarch64"`]("$architecture"_==_"aarch64" "wikilink")`â€‹ thenâ€‹ echoÂ "YourÂ computerÂ usesÂ theÂ 64-bitÂ ArmÂ architecture."â€‹ elseâ€‹ echoÂ "YourÂ computerÂ usesÂ anÂ unrecognizedÂ architecture."â€‹ fi

searchDocs.title: Age Checkâ€‹
searchDocs.content: This script checks whether a customer is of legal drinking age in Ontario:  #!/usr/bin/bashâ€‹ readÂ -pÂ "EnterÂ theÂ customer'sÂ dateÂ ofÂ birth:Â "Â Bâ€‹ â€‹ #Â CalculateÂ theÂ timeÂ inÂ secondsÂ thatÂ theÂ customerÂ turns/tunedÂ 19â€‹ D="$(dateÂ -dÂ "$BÂ +Â 19Â years"Â +%s)"â€‹ â€‹ #Â GetÂ theÂ currentÂ timeÂ inÂ seconds NOW="$(dateÂ +%s)"â€‹ #Â TellÂ theÂ userÂ ifÂ theÂ customerÂ isÂ oldÂ enoughÂ toÂ beÂ servedÂ alcoholâ€‹ #Â ThisÂ testsÂ checksÂ toÂ seeÂ ifÂ theÂ customer'sÂ 19thÂ birthdayÂ is #Â lessÂ thanÂ (before)Â theÂ currentÂ date. ifÂ `[`"$D" -lt "$NOW"`]("$D"_-lt_"$NOW" "wikilink")`â€‹ thenâ€‹ echoÂ "TheÂ customerÂ isÂ ofÂ legalÂ drinkingÂ ageÂ inÂ Ontario."â€‹ elseâ€‹ echoÂ "TheÂ customerÂ isÂ tooÂ youngÂ toÂ legallyÂ drinkÂ inÂ Ontario."â€‹ fi

searchDocs.title: Coinflipâ€‹
searchDocs.content: This script flips a virtual coin:  #!/usr/bin/bashâ€‹ COINFLIP=$((RANDOMÂ %Â 2))â€‹ #Â %Â isÂ theÂ modulusÂ operator ifÂ `[`"$COINFLIP" == 0`]("$COINFLIP"_==_0 "wikilink")`â€‹ thenâ€‹ echoÂ "Heads!Â ğŸ™‚"â€‹ elseâ€‹ echoÂ "TailsÂ ğŸ˜¦"â€‹ fi   The COINFLIP variable is set to the remainder of the division of$RANDOM by 2. Therefore, it will have a random value of 0 or 1.  Note that this script uses extended Unicode characters -- however, for these to display properly, your terminal and your terminal font must both support the extended characters. Besides emoji, extended characters may be used to display accented characters, symbols, and characters from other languages.

searchDocs.title: Cautious File Deleteâ€‹
searchDocs.content: This script checks a file, provided as a positional argument (parameter), to ensure that it is a regular file and is writable, and then asks the user if they want to delete it. Note that this script uses the -f (file) test, -w (writeable) test, and combines a number of string tests with the || (OR) operator:  #!/usr/bin/bashâ€‹ ifÂ `[`"$#" -ne 1`]("$#"_-ne_1 "wikilink")\ then echoÂ "$(basenameÂ $0):Â Error:Â oneÂ filenameÂ argumentÂ mustÂ beÂ provided."Â >&2 exitÂ 1 fi F="$1" #Â PutÂ theÂ firstÂ (andÂ only!)Â argumentÂ valueÂ intoÂ theÂ variableÂ F ifÂ [Â !Â -fÂ "$F"Â ]â€‹ thenâ€‹ echoÂ "TheÂ filenameÂ '$F'Â doesÂ notÂ referÂ toÂ aÂ regularÂ fileÂ -Â skipping."â€‹ elifÂ [Â !Â -wÂ "$F"Â ]â€‹ thenâ€‹ echoÂ "TheÂ fileÂ '$F'Â isÂ notÂ writeableÂ (byÂ you)Â -Â skipping."â€‹ elseâ€‹ readÂ -pÂ "DeleteÂ theÂ regularÂ fileÂ '$F'?Â (Y/N):Â "Â YESNOâ€‹ ifÂ [[Â "$YESNO"Â ==Â "Y"Â ||Â "$YESNO"Â ==Â "y"Â ||Â "$YESNO"Â ==Â "Yes"Â â€‹ ||Â "$YESNO"Â ==Â "yes"Â ||Â "$YESNO"Â ==Â "YES"Â ]]â€‹ thenâ€‹ echoÂ "DeletingÂ theÂ fileÂ '$F'..."â€‹ rmÂ "$F" #Â WeÂ shouldÂ addÂ someÂ codeÂ toÂ checkÂ ifÂ theÂ rmÂ succeedsÂ orÂ failsâ€‹ echoÂ "...done."â€‹ elseâ€‹ echoÂ "SkippingÂ theÂ fileÂ '$F'Â asÂ requested."â€‹ fiâ€‹ fi

searchDocs.title: Command Capture
searchDocs.content: Command Capture You can capture the output (stdout) of a command as a string using the notation \$( ) and then use that string in a variable assignment or as a command argument: $Â echoÂ "TheÂ currentÂ dateÂ andÂ timeÂ is:Â $(date)" TheÂ currentÂ dateÂ andÂ timeÂ is:Â MonÂ 19Â JunÂ 2034Â 12:02:11Â AMÂ EDT $Â FILES="$(ls|wcÂ -l)" $Â echoÂ "ThereÂ areÂ $FILESÂ filesÂ inÂ theÂ currentÂ directoryÂ $(pwd)" ThereÂ areÂ 2938Â filesÂ inÂ theÂ currentÂ directoryÂ /bin Avoid Backticks! You may see old scripts that use backticks (reverse single quotes) for command capture, like this: `` $Â A=`ls` ` This is an archaic syntax which is depricated -- avoid doing this. Some fonts make it hard to distiguish between backticks and single-quotes, and nesting backticks is difficult.

searchDocs.title: Conditional Logic: if / then / elif / else / fi
searchDocs.content: Conditional Logic: if / then / elif / else / fi Bash provides an if command to support conditional logic: ifÂ LIST1 then LIST2 fi If the command or commands in LIST1 execute successfully and return an exit status code of 0, then the commands in LIST2 are executed. For example, you could use a grep command as LIST1 and an echocommand as LIST2: ifÂ grepÂ -qÂ "OPS102"Â courses.txt then echoÂ "TheÂ courseÂ codeÂ 'OPS102'Â wasÂ foundÂ inÂ theÂ file." fi The if command also supports the else keyword: ifÂ grepÂ -qÂ "OPS102"Â courses.txt then echoÂ "TheÂ courseÂ codeÂ 'OPS102'Â wasÂ foundÂ inÂ theÂ file." else echoÂ "TheÂ courseÂ codeÂ 'OPS102'Â wasÂ NOTÂ foundÂ inÂ theÂ file." fi It also supports the elif (else-if) keyword: ifÂ grepÂ -qÂ "OPS102"Â courses.txt then echoÂ "TheÂ courseÂ codeÂ 'OPS102'Â wasÂ foundÂ inÂ theÂ file." elifÂ grepÂ -qÂ "ULI101"Â courses.txt then echoÂ "TheÂ courseÂ codeÂ 'ULI101'Â wasÂ foundÂ inÂ theÂ file. else echoÂ "NeitherÂ 'OPS102'Â norÂ 'ULI101'Â wasÂ foundÂ inÂ theÂ file." fi Putting this all together, you could have a script like this: #!/usr/bin/bash \ readÂ -pÂ "EnterÂ aÂ filename:Â "Â FILE \ ifÂ grepÂ -qÂ "OPS102"Â "$FILE" then echoÂ "TheÂ courseÂ codeÂ 'OPS102'Â wasÂ foundÂ inÂ theÂ fileÂ $FILE." elifÂ grepÂ -qÂ "ULI101"Â courses.txt then echoÂ "TheÂ courseÂ codeÂ 'ULI101'Â wasÂ foundÂ inÂ theÂ fileÂ $FILE. else echoÂ "NeitherÂ 'OPS102'Â norÂ 'ULI101'Â wasÂ foundÂ inÂ theÂ fileÂ $FILE." fi

searchDocs.title: Exit Status Codes
searchDocs.content: Exit Status Codes When any process finishes executing, it exits with a numeric value. This can be called the exit code, status code, exit status code, or error code. Usually, an exit status code of zero (0) means that no errors were encountered, and a non-zero code means that something went wrong. Therefore, it may be easiest to think of this as the error code, with 0 meaning no errors. Be aware that program authors can use this value as they see fit, so the status code may indicate something else, such as the number of data items processed. The special variable $? is set to the exit status code of the last command executed by the shell. For example: $Â lsÂ -dÂ /etc /etc $Â echoÂ $? 0 $Â lsÂ -dÂ /this/does/not/exist ls:Â cannotÂ accessÂ '/this/does/not/exist':Â NoÂ suchÂ fileÂ orÂ directory $Â echoÂ $? 2 Why is this important? Because exit status codes are the key to conditional logic (if...) and looping (for/while/until/...) in bash scripting.

searchDocs.title: Reading Variable Values from Stdin: read
searchDocs.content: Reading Variable Values from Stdin: read The read command reads a line of text from stdin and assigns it to the specified variable. For example, read A reads a line of text and assigns it to the variable A. The read command can also send a prompt to stdout using the -p option: $Â readÂ -pÂ "EnterÂ yourÂ name:Â "Â NAME EnterÂ yourÂ name:Â Chris $Â echoÂ $NAME Chris Here is a script which uses a couple of read statements: #!/usr/bin/bash readÂ -pÂ "PleaseÂ enterÂ yourÂ name:Â "Â NAME echoÂ "PleasedÂ toÂ meetÂ you,Â $NAME" readÂ -pÂ "PleaseÂ enterÂ aÂ filename:Â "Â FILE echoÂ "SavingÂ yourÂ nameÂ intoÂ theÂ file..." echoÂ "NAME=$NAME"Â >>$FILE echoÂ "Done."

searchDocs.title: Basic Requirements for Shell Scripts
searchDocs.content: Basic Requirements for Shell Scripts 1. Create a text file containing shell commands. Use any text editor (nano, vi, VS Code, gnome-text-editor, eclipse, ...) to create the file. 2. Tell the operating system which shell to use. Add a "shbang" line to the very top of the file, containing the text: #!/usr/bin/bash The first two chacters, the **sh**arp (#) and **bang** (!) give this line its name. They are recognized by the operating system kernel as identifying a script. The remainder of this line is interpreted by the kernel as the name of the shell which is to be used to interpret the script. In this case, /usr/bin/bash is the absolute path of the bash shell. You can substitute other interpreters to write scripts in other shell dialects (such as the Z-shell, /usr/bin/zsh) or languages (such as python, /usr/bin/python). Note that there must be nothing in font of the #! characters -- no space and no blank lines. 3. Ensure that the script has appropriate permissions. The kernel requires execute [x] permission, and the shell requires read [r] permission. Set this up with the chmod command (for example,chmod u+rx scriptname). Here is a simple example script using two commands, echo and date: #!/usr/bin/bash echoÂ "TheÂ currentÂ dateÂ andÂ timeÂ is:" date Notice the presence of the shbang line. If this is save into the file named "now", the permission could be set with this command: $Â chmodÂ u+rxÂ now The script can then be executed. Normally, the current working directory is not searched, so to run the a script in the current directory, you will need to explicitly specify the directory name like this: $Â ./now TheÂ currentÂ dateÂ andÂ timeÂ is: SatÂ Mar 6Â 12:03:32Â ESTÂ 2038

searchDocs.title: for VARIABLE in LISTâ€‹
searchDocs.content: This type of loop iterates through a list of values; the VARIABLE is sequentially set to the each of the items in the list of values and the body of the loop is executed for each value. The list of values may be constants:  forÂ XÂ inÂ 1Â 2Â 3 do ...Â bodyÂ ofÂ theÂ loopÂ ... done   forÂ COLOURÂ inÂ redÂ greenÂ blue do ...Â bodyÂ ofÂ theÂ loopÂ ... done   Or the list may be the list of parameters (arguments to the script), written as "$@":  forÂ AÂ inÂ "$@" do ...Â bodyÂ ofÂ theÂ loopÂ ... done   The most common use of this type of loop may be one or more globbing patterns (filename patterns with wildcard characters), which will be replaced with a list of all matching filenames:  forÂ SOURCEFILEÂ inÂ *.c do ...Â bodyÂ ofÂ theÂ loopÂ ... done   One thing to remember with this last form of the loop is that if the pattern does not match any file then the pattern itself will be assigned to the variable. For example, in the example above, if there are no files that match the pattern *.c then the variable SOURCEFILE will be set to the actual pattern: SOURCEFILE=*.c  This can be used in various ways. For example, this loop will compile all of the C source files found in the current directory:  forÂ SOURCEFILEÂ inÂ *.c do echoÂ "===Â CompilingÂ $SOURCEFILEÂ ===" #Â ThisÂ nextÂ lineÂ removesÂ theÂ extensionÂ fromÂ theÂ filename BINARY="$(echoÂ $SOURCEFILEÂ |Â cutÂ -d.Â -f1)" gccÂ SOURCEFILEÂ -oÂ $BINARY done   (It's also possible to generate the LIST in other ways -- for example, from the output of another command, captured with $( ) )

searchDocs.title: The "C-style" for loop: for (( ; ; ))â€‹
searchDocs.content: This loop is very similar to the "for" loop available in the C language. The C parenthesis are changed to bash double-parenthesis, to invoke the bash arithmetic syntax, and the curly-braces { } used in C are replaced by the bash do and done keywords. The three arguments in the double-parenthesis are the initial condition (variable initialization), the control condition (an expression that, while true, causes the loop to continue), and the increment/decrement (an expression which is executed at the end of each loop, which typically increments or decrements a counter).  For example, this loop counts from 1 to 10:  forÂ ((Â i=0;Â i<=10;Â i++Â )) do echoÂ $i done

searchDocs.title: while EXPRâ€‹
searchDocs.content: This loop continues as long as the expression EXPR is true:  whileÂ [[ "$A" == "$B" ]] do ...Â bodyÂ ofÂ theÂ loopÂ ... done   EXPR may be any single bash command, or a list of bash commands separated by newline characters (ENTER key) or semicolons, or a pipeline of commands. Most commonly it is a test [[ command.

searchDocs.title: until EXPRâ€‹
searchDocs.content: This loop continues as long as the expression EXPR is false:  untilÂ [[ "$X" -gt "$Y" ]] do ...Â bodyÂ ofÂ theÂ loopÂ ... done   This loop will continue as long as $X is less than or equal to $Y-- as soon as the expression becomes true (when $X is greater than$Y), the loop will stop. searchDocs.title: tput Colour Codesâ€‹
searchDocs.content: The tput command outputs terminal codes to stdout to perform actions such as setting the text colour, clearing the screen, and so forth.  The tput setaf n and tput setab n commands set the foreground and background text colours, respectively. To see the available colours, this script can be used:  #!/usr/bin/bash forÂ ((C=0;Â C<16;Â C++)) do tputÂ setafÂ $C #Â SetÂ foregroundÂ toÂ colourÂ $C echoÂ "ColourÂ $C" done tputÂ sgr0 #Â ResetÂ toÂ "normal"Â textÂ mode

searchDocs.title: Number-Guessing Gameâ€‹
searchDocs.content: This is the main example from the lecture. Study this code and ensure that you understand what it does (tip: test it, and alter it to see what effect your changes have):  #!/usr/bin/bash MAX=100 #Â MaximumÂ valueÂ ofÂ secret MAX_TRIES=7 #Â MaximumÂ numberÂ ofÂ triesÂ (guesses) GAMES=0 #Â HowÂ manyÂ gamesÂ haveÂ beenÂ played WINS=0 #Â HowÂ manyÂ gamesÂ theÂ userÂ hasÂ won clear #Â ClearÂ theÂ screen tputÂ setafÂ 5 #Â SelectÂ purpleÂ text echoÂ "===Â Number-GuessingÂ GameÂ ===" echo echoÂ "IÂ haveÂ aÂ secretÂ numberÂ betweenÂ 1Â andÂ $MAX" echoÂ "YourÂ missionÂ isÂ toÂ guessÂ itÂ inÂ asÂ fewÂ triesÂ asÂ possible." echoÂ "YouÂ haveÂ aÂ maximumÂ ofÂ $MAX_TRIESÂ guessesÂ toÂ succeed." echo PLAY="Y" #Â ThisÂ nextÂ loopÂ continuesÂ untilÂ theÂ userÂ says #Â theyÂ don'tÂ wantÂ toÂ playÂ again whileÂ [[Â "$PLAY"Â ==Â "Y"Â ||Â "$PLAY"Â ==Â "y"Â ||Â "$PLAY"Â ==Â "YES"Â || "$PLAY"Â ==Â "Yes"Â ||Â "$PLAY"Â ==Â "yes"Â ]] do #Â GenerateÂ aÂ randomÂ numberÂ fromÂ 1-MAX SECRET=$((Â RANDOMÂ %Â MAXÂ +Â 1Â )) #Â Un-commentÂ thisÂ lineÂ whenÂ debugging! #Â echoÂ "NOTE:Â theÂ secretÂ numberÂ isÂ $SECRET" GUESS=0 TRIES=0 ((GAMES++)) #Â ThisÂ nextÂ loopÂ continuesÂ untilÂ theÂ userÂ guessÂ correctly #Â orÂ theÂ maximumÂ numberÂ ofÂ guessesÂ isÂ exhausted untilÂ `[`| $TRIES -ge $MAX_TRIES `]($GUESS_-eq_$SECRET "wikilink")\ do tputÂ setafÂ 15 #Â WhiteÂ text readÂ -pÂ "EnterÂ yourÂ guessÂ (#$((++TRIES))):Â "Â GUESS ifÂ `[`$GUESS -gt $SECRET`]($GUESS_-gt_$SECRET "wikilink")\ then tputÂ setafÂ 1 #Â RedÂ text echoÂ "TooÂ high!" elifÂ `[`$GUESS -lt $SECRET`]($GUESS_-lt_$SECRET "wikilink")\ then tputÂ setafÂ 1 #Â RedÂ text echoÂ "TooÂ low!" else tputÂ setafÂ 10 #Â GreenÂ text echoÂ "YouÂ gotÂ itÂ inÂ $((TRIES))Â tries!" ((WINS++)) fi echo done ifÂ `[`! $GUESS -eq $SECRET`](!_$GUESS_-eq_$SECRET "wikilink")\ then tputÂ setafÂ 11 #Â YellowÂ text echoÂ "YouÂ loseÂ afterÂ $TRIESÂ attempts.Â TheÂ numberÂ wasÂ $SECRET.Â " fi tputÂ setafÂ 15 #Â WhiteÂ texxt echo readÂ -pÂ "DoÂ youÂ wantÂ toÂ playÂ againÂ (Y/N)?Â "Â PLAY echo done tputÂ setafÂ 5 #Â PurpleÂ text #Â InÂ theÂ nextÂ line,Â theÂ multiplication #Â mustÂ preceedÂ theÂ divisionÂ because #Â thisÂ isÂ integerÂ math echoÂ "YouÂ executedÂ $GAMESÂ missionsÂ andÂ succeededÂ $WINSÂ timesÂ ($((WINS*100/GAMES))%Â success)." echo tputÂ sgr0Â #Â ResetÂ toÂ normalÂ text

searchDocs.title: Parameters
searchDocs.content: Parameters Arguments to a script are called parameters. You can access the parameters using the special variables $0, $1, $2, and so forth. $0 contains the name of the script, $1 contains the first parameter, $2 contains the second parameter, and so forth. The special variable $# contains the total number of parameters. Here is a simple script which shows you what parameters have been received: #!/usr/bin/bashâ€‹ echoÂ "NumberÂ ofÂ parameters: $#"â€‹ echoÂ "ParameterÂ 0: $0"â€‹ echoÂ "ParameterÂ 1: $1"â€‹ echoÂ "ParameterÂ 2: $2"â€‹ echoÂ "ParameterÂ 3: $3"â€‹ echoÂ "ParameterÂ 4: $4" When you run this script with three parameters (red, green, and blue), you get this output: $Â ./paramsÂ redÂ greenÂ blueâ€‹ NumberÂ ofÂ parameters: 3â€‹ ParameterÂ 0: ./params ParameterÂ 1: redâ€‹ ParameterÂ 2: greenâ€‹ ParameterÂ 3: blueâ€‹ ParameterÂ 4: The shift command discards parameter $1 and moves each of the remaining parameters to the previous position (so the value in parameter$2 is moved to $1, and $3 is moved to $2). We can modify the previous script to demonstrate this: $Â catÂ params2â€‹ #!/usr/bin/bashâ€‹ echoÂ "NumberÂ ofÂ parameters: $#"â€‹ echoÂ "ParameterÂ 0: $0"â€‹ echoÂ "ParameterÂ 1: $1"â€‹ echoÂ "ParameterÂ 2: $2"â€‹ echoÂ "ParameterÂ 3: $3"â€‹ echoÂ "ParameterÂ 4: $4" echoÂ "----Â PerformingÂ shiftÂ ----" shift echoÂ "ParameterÂ 0: $0"â€‹ echoÂ "ParameterÂ 1: $1"â€‹ echoÂ "ParameterÂ 2: $2"â€‹ echoÂ "ParameterÂ 3: $3"â€‹ echoÂ "ParameterÂ 4: $4" $Â ./params2Â redÂ greenÂ blue NumberÂ ofÂ parameters: 3 ParameterÂ 0: ./params2 ParameterÂ 1: red ParameterÂ 2: green ParameterÂ 3: blue ParameterÂ 4: ----Â PerformingÂ shiftÂ ---- ParameterÂ 0: ./params2 ParameterÂ 1: green ParameterÂ 2: blue ParameterÂ 3: ParameterÂ 4: The shift command is useful for looping through parameters, and for accessing parameters higher than number 9.

searchDocs.title: Available Testsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: There are four main types of tests available:

searchDocs.title: Tests Group 1: Filesystem Entriesâ€‹
searchDocs.content: These tests check a filename to see if it is a regular file, a directory, or a symbolic link:  [`-f filename`](-f_filename "wikilink")` #Â TrueÂ ifÂ filenameÂ isÂ aÂ regularÂ file [`-d filename`](-d_filename "wikilink")` #Â TrueÂ ifÂ filenameÂ isÂ aÂ directory [`-L filename`](-L_filename "wikilink")` #Â TrueÂ ifÂ filenameÂ isÂ aÂ symbolicÂ link   Note: If a symbolic link points to a file, then both the-f and -l tests will succeed. If a symbolic link points to a directory, then both the -d and -l tests will succeed.

searchDocs.title: Tests Group 2: File Permissionsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: These tests check a filename to see if the person running the script can read, write, or execute the file (or access the directory):  [`-r filename`](-r_filename "wikilink")` #Â TrueÂ ifÂ filenameÂ isÂ readable [`-w filename`](-w_filename "wikilink")` #Â TrueÂ ifÂ filenameÂ isÂ writable [`-x filename`](-x_filename "wikilink")` #Â TrueÂ ifÂ filenameÂ isÂ executableÂ (accessibleÂ ifÂ aÂ directory)

searchDocs.title: Tests Group 3: Stringsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: These tests accept two string arguments, which are compared:  [`string1 == string2`](string1_==_string2 "wikilink")` #Â TrueÂ ifÂ theÂ stringsÂ areÂ equal [`string1 != string2`](string1_!=_string2 "wikilink")` #Â TrueÂ ifÂ theÂ stringsÂ areÂ notÂ equal [`string1 > string2`](string1_>_string2 "wikilink")` #Â TrueÂ ifÂ string1Â sortsÂ afterÂ string2Â lexicographically [`string1 < string2`](string1_<_string2 "wikilink")` #Â TrueÂ ifÂ string1Â sortsÂ beforeÂ string2Â lexicographically   A note on the term lexicographically: Sortinglexicographically means sorting according to character code. This is like sorting alphabetically, but it applies to non-alphabetic characters as well, such as digits and punctuation marks. See the manpage for "ascii" to see the sequence of the first 128 character codes (or refer to a Unicode table for all of the character codes).  When sorting lexicographically, a comes before aa, which comes before b:  a aa b   In a similar way, 1 comes before 11, which comes before 2:  1 11 2   Note that this is different from numeric order, where 2 would preceed 11:  1 2 11

searchDocs.title: Test Group 4: Integersâ€‹
searchDocs.content: These tests accept to integer arguments, which are compared:  [`integer1 -eq integer2`](integer1_-eq_integer2 "wikilink")` #Â IntegersÂ areÂ equal [`integer1 -ne integer2`](integer1_-ne_integer2 "wikilink")` #Â IntegersÂ areÂ notÂ equal [`integer1 -gt integer2`](integer1_-gt_integer2 "wikilink")` #Â Integer1Â isÂ greaterÂ thanÂ integer2 [`integer1 -ge integer2`](integer1_-ge_integer2 "wikilink")` #Â Integer1Â isÂ greaterÂ thanÂ orÂ equalÂ toÂ integer2 [`integer1 -lt integer2`](integer1_-lt_integer2 "wikilink")` #Â Integer1Â isÂ lessÂ thanÂ integer2 [`integer1 -le integer2`](integer1_-le_integer2 "wikilink")` #Â Integer1Â isÂ lessÂ thanÂ orÂ equalÂ toÂ integer2

searchDocs.title: Other Testsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: The four groups of tests above will cover the vast majority of situations. There are additional tests available to test other conditions, such as whether a variable is defined, or a file refers to a device. See the man page for bash(1) for more information if you're interested in other tests: man bash

searchDocs.title: Negating and Combining Testsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: The ! operator can be used to negate a test:  [`! -f "$FILE"`](!_-f_"$FILE" "wikilink")` #Â TrueÂ ifÂ "$FILE"Â isÂ notÂ aÂ fileÂ (doesn'tÂ exist,Â orÂ isÂ aÂ directory)   The AND operator && combines tests, with the result being True if the tests on the left and right are both true:  [`$A -lt $B && $B -lt $C`]($A_-lt_$B_&&_$B_-lt_$C "wikilink")` #Â TrueÂ ifÂ AÂ isÂ lessÂ thanÂ B,Â andÂ alsoÂ BÂ isÂ lessÂ thanÂ C.   The OR operator || combines tests, with the result being True if either of the tests are true:  [`| $A -lt 0 `]($A_-gt_$B "wikilink")`Â #Â TrueÂ ifÂ either:Â AÂ isÂ greaterÂ thanÂ B,Â orÂ ifÂ AÂ isÂ lessÂ thanÂ 0.   You can use multiple !, &&, and || operators toegether:  [`-f "$FILE" && -r "$FILE" && -w "$FILE"`](-f_"$FILE"_&&_-r_"$FILE"_&&_-w_"$FILE" "wikilink")`Â #Â TrueÂ ifÂ "$FILE"Â isÂ aÂ readable,Â writableÂ regularÂ file.

searchDocs.title: Tips on Using Testsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: RememberÂ toÂ quoteÂ anyÂ argumentsÂ whichÂ includeÂ whitespace,Â orÂ whichÂ mayÂ be nullÂ (empty).BeÂ carefulÂ withÂ theÂ <Â andÂ >Â comparisonÂ operators:Â ifÂ youÂ have aÂ syntaxÂ error,Â youÂ mayÂ accidentallyÂ redirectÂ dataÂ (whichÂ inÂ theÂ caseÂ ofÂ >Â mightÂ overwriteÂ aÂ file!)

searchDocs.title: Setting a Variableâ€‹
searchDocs.content: To set a variable, simply type the variable name, an equal sign, and the variable value:  A=5 B=World TheNameOfTheUser=Jason   If the variable does not exist, it will be created. If it does exist, the previous value will be discarded.  Variable names may contain letters, digits, or underscores, but must not start with a digit.  Unlike some computer languages such as C, variables do not need to be declared. Variables are not typed -- they may be used as strings, integers, or decimal values.  Note that there must not be a space on either side of the equal sign.

searchDocs.title: Accessing a Variableâ€‹
searchDocs.content: To access a variable, place a dollar sign [$] in front of it, and use it in a command as an argument (or as a command name):  $Â B=World $Â echoÂ $B World $Â echoÂ HelloÂ $B HelloÂ World

searchDocs.title: Word Splitting and Quotingâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Spaces and tabs are used to split a bash command line into individual "words". This means that if you use an argument that contains a space, it will be treated as two separate arguments:  $Â mkdirÂ test $Â cdÂ test #Â thisÂ isÂ newÂ soÂ itÂ willÂ beÂ empty $Â touchÂ newÂ file $Â lsÂ -l totalÂ 0 -rw-------Â 1Â chris.tylerÂ usersÂ 0Â Mar 6Â 12:12Â file -rw-------Â 1Â chris.tylerÂ usersÂ 0Â Mar 6Â 12:12Â new   Notice that touch new file created two files, because new and filewere treated as separate arguments.  To prevent word splitting, quote the text.  $Â mkdirÂ test $Â cdÂ test #Â thisÂ directoryÂ isÂ newÂ soÂ itÂ willÂ beÂ empty $Â touchÂ "newÂ file" $Â lsÂ -l totalÂ 0 -rw-------Â 1Â chris.tylerÂ usersÂ 0Â Mar 6Â 12:15Â newÂ file   Notice that only one file was created by the command touch \"new file\" because the quotes prevented word splitting, and the single argument new file was used as a single filename.  You'll also need to use quoting when assigning a string variable value containing a space:  $Â A="SenecaÂ Polytechnic"   You can quote text with single-quotes ['] or double-quotes ["]. Variable expansion takes place inside double quotes (this is calledinterpolation), but not inside single quotes:  $Â B=World $Â echoÂ "HelloÂ $B" #Â noticeÂ thatÂ $BÂ isÂ replacedÂ withÂ theÂ valueÂ ofÂ B HelloÂ World $Â echoÂ 'HelloÂ $B' #Â noticeÂ thatÂ $BÂ usedÂ as-in HelloÂ $B   You should always double-quote variables that may contain a space in their value when using them as command arguments. This is especially true for filenames -- you never know when a user is going to put a space in a filename! Many scripts work find with opaque filenames (those containing no whitespace) but fail with non-opaque names.  Here is an example -- the difference between the first ls statement (which does not double-quote the variable) and the second ls statement (where the variable expansion is double-quoted):  $Â touchÂ "redÂ maple" $Â FILE="redÂ maple" $Â lsÂ $FILE ls:Â cannotÂ accessÂ 'red':Â NoÂ suchÂ fileÂ orÂ directory ls:Â cannotÂ accessÂ 'maple':Â NoÂ suchÂ fileÂ orÂ directory $Â lsÂ "$FILE" 'redÂ maple'

searchDocs.title: Backslashesâ€‹
searchDocs.content: A backslash [\] character outside of quotes or inside double quotes instructs the shell to ignore any special meaning that the following character may have. Examples:  $Â touchÂ "newÂ file" $Â lsÂ -lÂ new\Â file #Â TheÂ spaceÂ losesÂ itsÂ specialÂ meaningÂ asÂ anÂ argumentÂ separator -rw-r--r--.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 0Â JunÂ 18Â 22:49Â 'newÂ file' $Â echoÂ "ThisÂ stringÂ containsÂ aÂ \"quoted\"Â string" ThisÂ stringÂ containsÂ aÂ "quoted"Â string $Â A=Testing $Â echoÂ " \$A" #Â TheÂ dollarÂ signÂ losesÂ itsÂ specialÂ meaning $A

searchDocs.title: What is a script?
searchDocs.content: What is a script? A shell script is a computer program which isinterpreted by an operating system shell. Scipts are used to automate procedures that could be manually performed from the command line. They can potentially save a huge amount of time by eliminating repetitive commands. For example, if you're going to compile and test a program 100x, and each compilation and test cycle requires 25 steps (commands), you're looking at performing 2500 steps. It's much more efficient to create a script containing those 25 steps and run it as needed -- in fact, you can even set things up so those commands execute automatically as soon as you save a new version of your program.

searchDocs.title: Arithmetic
searchDocs.content: Arithmetic CMD can perform integer arithmetic. To evaluate an arithmetic expressions and store the results in a variable, use the SET command with the /A (arithmetic) option. (Note: when used interactively the result of the expressions evaluation will be output to stdout; this does not happen inside scripts). >Â SETÂ A=100 >Â SETÂ B=12 >Â SETÂ /AÂ X=A*B 1200 :: <---Â ThisÂ doesÂ notÂ getÂ printedÂ insideÂ aÂ script >Â ECHOÂ %X% 1200 >Â SETÂ /AÂ A+=1Â >Â NUL: >Â ECHOÂ %A% 101 >Â SETÂ /AÂ C=A*B*2Â >Â NUL: >Â ECHOÂ TheÂ answerÂ isÂ %C% TheÂ answerÂ isÂ 2424 Notes: YouÂ canÂ performÂ moreÂ thanÂ oneÂ arithmeticÂ evaluationÂ andÂ assignmentÂ inÂ oneÂ SETÂ commandÂ byÂ separatingÂ theÂ expressionsÂ withÂ aÂ commaÂ [,]SomeÂ charactersÂ usedÂ inÂ arithmeticÂ expressions,Â suchÂ asÂ theÂ caratÂ symbol,Â mayÂ needÂ toÂ beÂ quotedÂ orÂ escapedÂ toÂ functionÂ correctly.â€‹PercentÂ signs,Â whenÂ usedÂ inÂ arithmeticÂ expressionsÂ (asÂ theÂ moduloÂ operator),Â needÂ toÂ beÂ doubledÂ [%%]Â toÂ avoidÂ confusionÂ withÂ theÂ percentÂ signsÂ placedÂ aroundÂ variableÂ namesâ€‹

searchDocs.title: Basic Requirements for Shell Scripts
searchDocs.content: Basic Requirements for Shell Scripts Remember these requirements? They apply to Windows scripts too: 1. Create a text file containing shell commands.â€‹ Use any text editor, such as Notepad, to create the file. 2. Tell the operating system which shell to use to execute the commands. In Windows, the filename extension is used to associate a file with a program, and this mechanism is used to associate a scriptwith a command interpreter.â€‹ â€‹ ForÂ CMDÂ scripts,Â theÂ extensionÂ ".cmd"Â isÂ used.â€‹Â ForÂ historicalÂ reasons,Â theÂ extensionÂ ".bat"Â isÂ alsoÂ accepted.â€‹ForÂ PowerShellÂ scripts,Â theÂ extensionÂ ".ps1"Â isÂ used.â€‹Â TheÂ reasonÂ thatÂ ".ps"Â isn'tÂ usedÂ isÂ thatÂ thatÂ extensionÂ wasÂ alreadyÂ usedÂ forÂ PostScriptÂ files.â€‹Â (AsÂ aÂ reminder:Â We'reÂ notÂ goingÂ toÂ writeÂ PowerShellÂ scriptsÂ inÂ thisÂ course).â€‹ 3. Ensure that the script file has the appropriate permissions.â€‹On Windows, the ability to read the script file is sufficient (and this is the default permission, so no change is usually required for scripts that you create for your own use; the situation may be different for scripts that are shared to other machines over the network or to otherusers on your system).â€‹

searchDocs.title: A Basic CMD Script Example
searchDocs.content: A Basic CMD Script Example Here is a simple example script using two commands, echo and date: @echoÂ off echoÂ TheÂ currentÂ dateÂ is: dateÂ /t The script can then be executed. Normally, the current working directory is not searched, so to run the a script in the current directory, you will need to explicitly specify the directory name like this: >Â now TheÂ currentÂ dateÂ is: 2024-12-11

searchDocs.title: Command Echosâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Command Echosâ€‹ Windows defaults to displaying each command in a script before executing it (the opposite of the default in the bash shell). If you do not wanteach command to be displayed, you can:â€‹ AddÂ anÂ @Â signÂ inÂ frontÂ ofÂ eachÂ command,Â orâ€‹IssueÂ theÂ echoÂ offÂ command.â€‹ Usually, you'll combine these in a script, using this as one of thefirst lines:â€‹ @echoÂ offâ€‹

''DIR \FileThatDoesNotExist ''\ ''ECHO %ERRORLEVEL%'' PATH	A semicolon [;] separated list of directories that will be searched when looking for a command	''PATH="$PATH;\SpecialDirectory"'' PROMPT	The prompt presented by the shell.	''SET PROMPT=Enter a command: ''\ ''SET PROMPT=PPPG '' RANDOM	A random integer (0-32767)	ECHO %RANDOM%  Note that the prompt and path programs may also be used to adjust the PROMPT and PATH environment variables, respectively.

searchDocs.title: An Abundance of Shellsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: We've looked at scripting on Linux systems using the bash shell -- which is the most widely-deployed shell on Linux and other Unix-likesystems. There are many other shells on similar systems, including:â€‹  shÂ â€“Â theÂ originalÂ UnixÂ shellÂ ("BourneÂ Shell"),Â writtenÂ byÂ StevenÂ Bourneâ€‹kshÂ â€“Â theÂ KornÂ shell,Â writtenÂ byÂ DavidÂ Kornâ€‹cshÂ â€“Â theÂ CÂ shell,Â whichÂ hasÂ aÂ C-likeÂ syntaxâ€‹fishÂ â€“Â theÂ FriendlyÂ InteractiveÂ shellâ€‹ZshÂ â€“Â theÂ ZÂ shell,Â similarÂ toÂ kshâ€‹  Many of these have a syntax based on and similar to the original Bourne shell, which is standardized in the POSIX.1 standard (or IEEE Standard1003.1), and these shells have a lot in common.â€‹  On Windows, there are two main shells:  CMDÂ -Â TheÂ WindowsÂ commandÂ shell,Â whichÂ isÂ theÂ traditionalÂ WindowsÂ shell. AlthoughÂ basedÂ onÂ traditionalÂ DOSÂ commandÂ syntax,Â theÂ CMDÂ shellÂ hasÂ beenÂ considerablyÂ expanded,Â withÂ manyÂ newÂ featuresÂ addedÂ overÂ theÂ lastÂ fewÂ years.â€‹ PowerShellÂ â€“Â thisÂ isÂ aÂ newÂ WindowsÂ commandÂ shell,Â whichÂ combinesÂ scripting withÂ object-orientedÂ programming.Â ItÂ isÂ pre-installedÂ forÂ interactiveÂ useÂ on currentÂ WindowsÂ systems;Â however,Â theÂ executionÂ ofÂ PowerShellÂ scriptsÂ is disabledÂ byÂ defaultÂ onÂ allÂ WindowsÂ "client"Â (non-server)Â systems,Â includingÂ SenecaÂ labÂ computers.â€‹  â€‹Due to PowerShell scripting being disabled by default, and because object oriented programming is not taught in the first semester programming courses, we will focus on scripting using the traditionalWindows CMD shell.â€‹

searchDocs.title: Cross-Platform Scriptingâ€‹
searchDocs.content: There are several possible approaches to writing scripts that will work on both Linux and Windows systems, as well as other common operatingsystems such as Mac OS:â€‹  BashÂ orÂ ZshÂ â€“Â bashÂ isÂ theÂ defaultÂ shellÂ onÂ mostÂ LinuxÂ systems,Â andÂ zsh isÂ theÂ defaultÂ shellÂ onÂ mostÂ MacÂ OSÂ systems;Â eitherÂ shellÂ canÂ beÂ easily usedÂ onÂ eitherÂ system.Â BothÂ shellsÂ areÂ availableÂ asÂ third-partyÂ add-ons forÂ theÂ WindowsÂ operatingÂ system,Â usuallyÂ shippedÂ withÂ aÂ collectionÂ of GNUÂ utilitiesÂ compiledÂ forÂ useÂ withÂ WindowsÂ (forÂ example, seeÂ https:gitforwindows.org/)â€‹ PowerShellÂ â€“Â installedÂ byÂ defaultÂ onÂ currentÂ WindowsÂ systems,Â itÂ isÂ also availableÂ forÂ LinuxÂ andÂ MacÂ OSÂ systems,Â althoughÂ itÂ isÂ notÂ commonlyÂ usedÂ on thoseÂ systemsÂ yetÂ (seeÂ https:*github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell)â€‹

searchDocs.title: Other Interpreted Languagesâ€‹
searchDocs.content: In addition to shell scripting languages, there are other interpreted languages that are well suited for cross-platform development, includingPython and Perl.â€‹  â€‹When should you use a shell scripting langauge?â€‹  ShellÂ scriptingÂ languagesÂ areÂ ideallyÂ suitedÂ forÂ processÂ controlÂ â€“Â executing,Â managing,Â andÂ combiningÂ externalÂ programsÂ toÂ accomplishÂ tasks.â€‹ ShellÂ scriptingÂ languagesÂ areÂ notÂ well-suitedÂ forÂ implementingÂ advanced processingÂ algorithms,Â becauseÂ theyÂ generallyÂ lackÂ featuresÂ suchÂ asÂ good floating-pointÂ support,Â typedÂ variables,Â andÂ strongÂ supportÂ forÂ largeÂ arraysÂ andÂ hashes.â€‹

searchDocs.title: Windows "Shell Scripts" vs. Batch Files"â€‹
searchDocs.content: DOS and early Windows systems were inherently interactive in nature, and early scripts were called "batch files" because they were viewed assimilar to non-interactive batch processing on mainframe systems.â€‹  This terminology has stuck, and Windows shell scripts are still often called "batch files" (hence the occasional use of the .bat extensioninstead of .cmd).â€‹â€‹  The concept of a "batch file" and a "shell script" are roughlyequivalent.â€‹

searchDocs.title: Delayed Expansionâ€‹
searchDocs.content: When the body of a FOR loop is executed, the variables are expanded (replaced by their values) before the loop begins. That means that any variables that are contained in the loop have their values locked-in andthey can't be changed while the loop is executing.â€‹  To allow updated variable values to be accessed within a loop:â€‹  1. Set the EnableDelayedExpansion option:â€‹  SETLOCALÂ EnableDelayedExpansionâ€‹   â€‹2. Change any variables which will be updated during the execution of the loop by replacing the percent-signs ( % ) with exclaimation-marks (! ):â€‹  %ERRORLEVEL% -> !ERRORLEVEL!â€‹

searchDocs.title: Loop throush a List of Files or Parametersâ€‹
searchDocs.content: To loop through a list of values such as filenames, use:  FORÂ %variableÂ INÂ (files)Â DOÂ listâ€‹   The variable will be sequentially set to each of the given filesvalues, and the loop body (list) will be executed once for each value.  The files value may be:  AÂ listÂ ofÂ filenames:Â FOR %F IN (file1.txt file2.pdf file3.c) DO ECHO %FAÂ filenameÂ pattern:Â FOR %F IN (*.pdf) DO ECHO %FFixedÂ strings:Â FOR %C IN (Red Green Blue) DO ECHO %COrÂ aÂ listÂ ofÂ allÂ ofÂ theÂ parameters:Â FOR %P IN (%*) DO ECHO %P  The /D option can be used along with a filename pattern to match only directories:  FORÂ /DÂ %variableÂ INÂ (files)Â DOÂ list

searchDocs.content: @echo offâ€‹ SETLOCAL EnableDelayedExpansionâ€‹ FOR %%F IN (\*) DO (â€‹ remÂ TheÂ CHOICEÂ commandÂ presentsÂ aÂ Y/NÂ choiceÂ andÂ setsÂ %ERRORLEVEL% remÂ toÂ 1Â ifÂ theÂ userÂ selectedÂ YÂ andÂ 2Â ifÂ theÂ userÂ selectedÂ N CHOICEÂ /MÂ "DELETEÂ %%F"â€‹ IFÂ !ERRORLEVEL!==1Â (â€‹ ECHOÂ ...DeletingÂ %%Fâ€‹ DELÂ %%Fâ€‹ )Â ELSEÂ (â€‹ ECHOÂ ...SkippingÂ %%Fâ€‹ )â€‹

searchDocs.content: FORÂ /LÂ (start,Â step,Â end)Â DOÂ list   This type of loop counts forward or backwards from start to end by a given step.  Example:â€‹ â€‹  @echoÂ offâ€‹ remÂ CountÂ fromÂ 0Â toÂ 5Â inÂ incrementsÂ ofÂ 1â€‹ FORÂ /LÂ %%IÂ INÂ (0, 1,Â 5)Â DOÂ ECHOÂ ...Â %%IÂ ...â€‹ remÂ CountÂ fromÂ 4Â toÂ 0Â inÂ incrementsÂ ofÂ -1â€‹ FORÂ /LÂ %%IÂ INÂ (4,Â -1,Â 0)Â DOÂ ECHOÂ ...Â %%IÂ ...   Output:  0 1 2 3 4 5 <-Â ThisÂ isÂ theÂ endÂ ofÂ outputÂ fromÂ theÂ firstÂ loop,Â havingÂ goneÂ fromÂ 0Â toÂ 5 4 <-Â TheÂ secondÂ loopÂ startsÂ outputÂ here,Â goingÂ fromÂ 4Â toÂ 0 3 2 1 0

searchDocs.title: Available Testsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: There are four main types of tests available:

searchDocs.title: Tests Group 1: Filesystem Entriesâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Tests that a filename exists (regardless of the entry type: file or directory):  EXISTÂ filename

searchDocs.title: Tests Group 2: String Equalityâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Test for string equality:  `string1`*`==`*`string2`

searchDocs.title: Tests Group 3: String and Numeric Comparisonsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: These tests accept two string arguments, both strings or both integers, which are compared. Adding the /i switch will make string comparisonscase-insensitive (UPPER/lowercase).â€‹  value1Â EQUÂ value2 TrueÂ ifÂ theÂ valuesÂ areÂ equalâ€‹ value1Â NEQÂ value2 TrueÂ ifÂ theÂ valuesÂ areÂ notÂ equalâ€‹ value1Â LSSÂ value2 TrueÂ ifÂ theÂ value1Â lessÂ thanÂ value2Â â€‹ value1Â LEQÂ value2 TrueÂ ifÂ theÂ value1Â less/equalÂ toÂ value2â€‹ value1Â GTRÂ value2 TrueÂ ifÂ theÂ value1Â greaterÂ thanÂ value2â€‹ value1Â GEQÂ value2 TrueÂ ifÂ theÂ value1Â greaterÂ thanÂ orÂ equalÂ toÂ toÂ value2â€‹   To force a string comparison, enclose value1 and value2 in quotes. Otherwise, the shell will determine if the variables appear to contain integer values and compare them as integers, or otherwise compare them as strings.

searchDocs.content: TheseÂ testsÂ workÂ onlyÂ withÂ theÂ *IF*Â commandTheÂ IFÂ commandÂ canÂ beÂ usedÂ withÂ *GOTO*Â andÂ aÂ label:  IFÂ testÂ GOTOÂ :skipâ€‹ ...â€‹ :skipâ€‹   Note that using a GOTO in a loop will make the shell forget about theloop, regardless of where the label is located!â€‹

searchDocs.title: Negating and Combining Testsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: You can negate (invert) a test with the NOT operator:  IFÂ NOTÂ EXISTÂ %N%Â ECHOÂ TheÂ fileÂ %N%Â doesÂ notÂ exist.   Note that you cannot combine tests - there is no AND or OR operator.

searchDocs.title: Script Parameters
searchDocs.content: Script Parameters Arguments to a script are called parameters. You can access the parameters using the special variables %0, %1, %2, and so forth.%0 contains the name of the script, %1 contains the first parameter,%2 contains the second parameter, and so forth. (Note that there is no second percent sign after the parameter number!) The shift command gets rid of the first parameter and shifts everyparameter to a lower number.â€‹ Examples: >Â typeÂ params.cmdâ€‹ @echoÂ offâ€‹ ECHOÂ PARAMÂ 0:Â %0â€‹ ECHOÂ PARAMÂ 1:Â %1â€‹ ECHOÂ PARAMÂ 2:Â %2â€‹ >Â paramsÂ redÂ greenÂ blueâ€‹ PARAMÂ 0:Â paramsâ€‹ PARAMÂ 1:Â redâ€‹ PARAMÂ 2:Â greenâ€‹ >Â typeÂ params-shift.cmdâ€‹ @echoÂ offâ€‹ ECHOÂ ListÂ ofÂ allÂ arguments:Â %*â€‹ :startâ€‹ IFÂ "%1"==""Â GOTOÂ :doneâ€‹ ECHOÂ %1â€‹ SHIFTâ€‹ GOTOÂ :startâ€‹ :doneâ€‹ >Â params-shiftÂ yellowÂ orangeÂ redâ€‹ ListÂ ofÂ allÂ arguments:Â yellowÂ orangeÂ redâ€‹ yellowâ€‹ orangeâ€‹ red The special variable %* returns all of the parameters. On the command line, parameters may be separated by: SpaceÂ (orÂ Tab)CommaÂ [,]SemicolonÂ [;]EqualÂ signÂ [=]

searchDocs.content: There is no direct equivalient to command capture, but it is possible to use SET /P with redirection from standard input using the less-than [<] symbol to capture one line of text:  >Â DATEÂ /TÂ >X >Â SETÂ /PÂ D=Â ``<X >Â ECHOÂ %D% 2024-12-11

searchDocs.title: Basic Commands for Dealing with Files and Directories
searchDocs.content: Basic Commands for Dealing with Files and Directories Here are some basic commands for creating and removing files and directories, changing and displaying the current directory, and displaying a tree diagram of a directory hierarchy. We will look at other commands in future topics. Description	Linux Command	Windows Command	NotesMake a Directory	mkdir directory	mkdir directory Remove a Directory (Must be empty)	rmdir directory	rmdir directory Change (Working) Directory	cd directory	cd directory Print Current Working Directory	pwd	cd Change to Home Directory	cd List Contents of Directory	ls ls -l	dir	Linux: -l option displays long listing (including permissions, ownership, size, modification date/time) Create an Empty File	touch file	copy nul file Remove/Delete a File	rm file	del file Display a Tree Diagram starting at Current Directory	tree	tree tree /f	Windows: /f causes tree to display files (otherwise only directories are shown) Copy a file	cp sourcefile destinationfile	copy sourcefile destinationfile Move or rename a file	mv currentfilename newfilename	move currentfilename newfilename Display the text contents of a file	cat file	type file	Note: Using these commands on a file that contains non-text data may look very strange.

searchDocs.title: Setting a Variableâ€‹
searchDocs.content: To set a variable, use the set keyword with a variable name, an equal sign, and the variable value:  setÂ A=5 setÂ B=World   If the variable does not exist, it will be created. If it does exist, the previous value will be discarded.  Variable names may contain letters, digits, or underscores, but must not start with a digit. Case does not matter! The variable names Number,number, and NUMBER all refer to the same variable.  Do not put spaces on either side of the equal sign.  Variables are not typed -- they may be used as strings, integers, or decimal values.

searchDocs.title: Accessing a Variableâ€‹
searchDocs.content: To access a variable, place a percent sign [%] on either side of it, and use it in a command as an argument (or as a command name):  >Â SETÂ B=World >Â echoÂ %B% World >Â echoÂ HelloÂ $B HelloÂ World

searchDocs.title: Word Splitting and Quotingâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Quoting in the Windows shell is very different from Bash!  Using single or double quotes causes the quotes themselves to be included as part of the string or argument in most cases, but not whendealing with a filename:â€‹  >Â ECHOÂ "Hello"â€‹ "Hello"â€‹ >Â ECHOÂ testÂ >Â "testÂ file"â€‹   â€‹Quoting is not required when assigning a string value which contains spaces to a variable:  >Â SETÂ A=OneÂ TwoÂ Three >Â ECHOÂ %A% OneÂ TwoÂ Three

searchDocs.title: Carat Symbolsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Escaping characters to remove their special meaning is performed using the carat [^] symbol in Windows.â€‹ In this example, the ampersand [&] symbol would normally cause an error, but it can be treated as a regular character by escaping it with a carat:  >Â echoÂ LostÂ ^&Â Found LostÂ &Â Found   When piping, a CMD subshell is started for each command in the pipeline, and it is necessary to use triple carat symbols ^^^ to escapecharacters:â€‹  >Â echoÂ LostÂ ^^^&Â FoundÂ |Â findÂ "Lost"Â â€‹ LostÂ &Â FoundÂ â€‹

searchDocs.title: Current Working Directory (or Working Directory or Current Directory)
searchDocs.content: Current Working Directory (or Working Directory or Current Directory) Most operating systems have the concept of a current directory orworking directory, which allows a directory to be temporarily designated as the current working location. The working directory may be changed at any time. To change the current working directory on Linux or on Windows, use thecd command followed by a directory name: cdÂ ops102 To see the name of the current directory, use the command pwd (Print Working Directory) on Linux or cd on Windows. To change your current directory to your home directory on Linux, use the cd command by itself (with no arguments).

searchDocs.title: Hierarchical File Systems
searchDocs.content: Hierarchical File Systems Most modern computers are equipped with one or more random-access storage devices -- either a mechanical hard disk drive (HDD), or a fully electronic solid state disk (SSD). Both of these provide a numbered set of blocks or sectors, each of which stores a set amount of data (typically 512 or 1024 bytes). However, accessing storage as numbered blocks is very inconvenient for computer users! In order to conveniently use this storage, it is arranged intofiles, which are named collections of bytes of arbitrary length. The organization of blocks/sectors into files is handled by afilesystem, which is a scheme for structuring data, along with the corresponding software to implement this scheme. Most filesystems track metadata about a file in addition to the file name (usually written as "filename"), such as the date/time of creation, the date/time of last modification, the owner or original creator of the file, and the permissions applicable to the file (for example, who is permitted to read and to change the file contents). A hierarchical filesystem introduces the concept of directories, which are special files which hold zero or more other files. The files in a directory may themselves be directories, enabling files to be nested into an arbitrary hierarchy. The master directory is called theroot directory. When graphical user interfaces were developed, the metaphor of a traditional paper-based office was introduced, and directories were called folders in this metaphor (a folder in a traditional office is a piece of card stock folded in half to group together related papers). Therefore, the terms directory and folder are synonyms.

searchDocs.title: Volume Designators
searchDocs.content: Volume Designators On Windows systems, a volume designator consisting of a letter followed by a colon may prefix a pathname. The volume may be a partition on a disk drive (HDD or SSD), a shortcut to a network storage location, or a multi-drive volume, where multiple partitions or disks are combined into a single storage pool. Since the original IBM PC was designed to have up to two floppy disk drives, designated A: and B:, the main/first disk drive in a Windows system is usually designated as volume C: Therefore, the \Windows folder on the main/first disk drive on a Windows system may be referred to as C:\Windows The volume designator is case-insensitive. Each unique volume on a Windows system has its own current/working directory. You can switch between volumes by typing the volume designator by itself. On a Linux system, instead of using drive designators, volumes aremounted into the filesystem hierarchy -- that is, volumes are attached as directories, creating a unified hierarchy with a single root directory.

searchDocs.title: Extensionsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Many operating systems use an extension at the end of a filename to denote the type of data stored in the file. These extensions are delimited by a period followed by one or more characters. For example, in the filename:  ops102_project.pdf   The extension is "pdf", denoting a file in Portable Document Format.  It is unusual to use multiple extensions on a Windows system, but not uncommon on a Linux (or other Unix-like) system.  For example, on a Linux system, the filename  backup.tar.gz   has two extensions, "tar" indicating a archive created with the tarcommand, and "gz" indiciating that the file was compressed with thegzip command.

searchDocs.title: Case Sensitivityâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Some filesystems are case-sensitive, and UPPER- and lower-case letters are considered to be different. For example, the filenames MILK.PDF,Milk.pdf, and milk.pdf refer to three different files. This is the case with most Linux (and Unix-like) filesystems.  Most Windows filesystems are not case-sensitive, so the filesnamesMILK.PDF, Milk.pdf, and milk.pdf would refer to the same file.

searchDocs.title: 1. Absolute Pathnamesâ€‹
searchDocs.content: An absolute pathname starts with a slash (on Unix-based operating systems, such as Linux), or a backslash (on Windows), indicating the root directory. It contains the names of all of the directories from the root directory to the specified file, separated by slash/backslash characters.  For example, on a Linux system, the pathname   /home/kim/ops102/presentation.pdf   indicates that the file presentation.pdf can be found by starting at the root directory, then traversing to a directory named "home" containing the directory "kim" containing the directory "ops102" containing the file ("presentation.pdf").  Similarly, the Windows pathname   \Users\kim\ops102\presentation.pdf   indicates that the file presentation.pdf can be found by starting at the root directory, then traversing to a directory named "Users" containin the directory "kim" containing the directory "ops102" containing the file ("presentation.pdf").  Absolute pathnames can be readily identified by the fact that they start with the slash/backslash character. They are often the longest form of the pathname, but they are unambiguous.

searchDocs.title: 2. Relative-to-Home Pathnamesâ€‹
searchDocs.content: On Linux (and other Unix-like operating systems), pathnames may be specified starting with the tilde ("~") character followed by a slash, which represents the current user's home directory. This is a directory assigned by the system administrator which contains all of the user's personal files. The home directory is usually (but not always)/home/username**.  For example, if the current user's home directory is /home/kim, then the filename  ~/ops102/presentation.pdf   corresponds to the absolute pathname  /home/kim/ops102/presentation.pdf   For any file in the user's home directory, a relative-to-home pathname is generally shorter than an absolute pathanme. However, a relative-to-home pathname will have a different meaning for other users, since each user has a unique home directory.  You can also specify the user whose home directory is to be used as the starting point, by placing the a userid between the tilde and slash characters. Thus the pathanme  ~kim/ops102/presentation.pdf   is relative to the home directory of the user "kim", regardless of which user is currently logged in, while the pathname  ~sam/ops102/presentation.pdf   is relative to the home directory of the user "sam".

searchDocs.title: 3. Relative Pathnamesâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Any pathname that does not start with a slash/backslash or a tilde character is a relative pathname, which is interpreted as starting at the current directory.  If the current directory is /home/kim/ops102, then the Linux pathname   presentation.pdf   is interpreted as  /home/kim/ops102/presentation.pdf   The symbol ".." means the parent directory. Assuming the same current directory as above (/home/kim/ops102), the Linux pathname  ../Downloads/example.txt   Is interpreted as  /home/kim/Downloads/example.txt   In the same way, the symbol "." is interpreted as referring to the current directory, so  ./test.odt   is the same as  test.odt   and both refer to  /home/kim/ops102/test.odt   Likewise, if the current directory on a Windows system was\Users\kim, then the pathaname  ops102\presentation.pdf   refers to the absolute pathname  \Users\kim\ops102\presentation.pdf   And the relative pathname  ..\jdoe\Downloads\example.txt   refers to the absolute pathname  \Users\jdoe\Downloads\example.txt   Relative pathnames are often the shortest form of pathname if the target file is in the current working directory or a subdirectory of the current working directory, but the meaning of a relative pathname changes based on the current working directory.  Directory vs File Names  It is often impossible to tell whether a pathname refers to a file or to a directory. For example, the Linux pathname /home/chris/presentationmight refer to a file named presentation or to a directory namedpresentation.  If you wish to explicitly indicate that a pathname refers to a directory, append a slash or backslash to the pathname.

searchDocs.title: The Kernelâ€‹
searchDocs.content: This is the heart of the operating system, the main program (or group of programs) that controls the computer. The kernel operates in a special privileged mode, which allows it to manage the resources and security settings for all other software. The kernel is loaded by the computer's firmware (built-in software) and sets up the computer's hardware and resources before starting the services and user interface(s) in non-privileged mode, controlling the computer's hardware to enforce the privilege level.

searchDocs.title: System Librariesâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Many programs need to perform the same operations, such as accessing the network, playing sound, or drawing something on the screen. Libraries provide a common set of software routines (also known as functions, methods, procedures, or subroutines) which programs access to perform these common operations. This eliminates the need for each program to contain duplicate code for these common operations, which reduces software duplication and program size. Although additional libraries may be installed on the computer, the system libraries provided as part of the operating system provide the most broadly-used routines required by nearly every program.

searchDocs.title: Servicesâ€‹
searchDocs.content: These are programs that run continuously in the background, providing services such as WiFi authentication, print management, and file sharing. Unlike the kernel, these programs don't operate with full system privilege, and are therefore subject to the same type of resource and security management as regular programs, and they also utilize the system libraries.

searchDocs.title: The User Interface(s)â€‹
searchDocs.content: This is the software that enables the user to interact with the system. Most operating systems provide at least two user interfaces:  1. A text-based user interface that enables the user to enter commands, view the output from those commands, and interact with full-screen text interfaces such as file editors and file managers. This may be referred to as a text user interface (TUI) or a command line interface (CLI). Here are command line interfaces on Windows, Linux, and Android systems displaying similar information:    2. A graphical user interface (GUI) that typically enables the user to interact with multiple application windows, using a keyboard and a pointing device such as a mouse, trackpad, or touchscreen. Here are graphical user interfaces on Windows and Linux systems showing similar capabilities and information:

searchDocs.title: Utilities and Applicationsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Most operating systems provide a set of tools to enable users to perform setup, configuration, and maintenance tasks. For example, they may provide "utility" software to add/remove software, configure hardware, and manage files. This utility software may take the form of commands that are accessed through a CLI, or graphical utilities that are accessed through a GUI. Most operating systems also provide a set of basic starter applications, such as a text editor, clock, a few games, and sometimes a web browser; the quantity and complexity of the included applications vary considerably from one operating system to another.

searchDocs.title: Anatomy of a Command Line Interface (CLI)
searchDocs.content: Anatomy of a Command Line Interface (CLI) A CLI is provided by two programs: 1. AÂ terminalÂ program,Â whichÂ isÂ responsibleÂ forÂ collectingÂ userÂ input andÂ displayingÂ theÂ outputÂ fromÂ theÂ shellÂ andÂ commands. 2. AÂ shell,Â whichÂ interpretsÂ theÂ user'sÂ writtenÂ commands. These may be on the same machine, or they may be on different computers. For example, it is common to access both Linux and Windows systems over a remote connection, using a protocol such as SSH ("secure shell", which protects the connection using encryption). In that case, the terminal program runs on the computer in front of the user, and the shell runs on the remote computer system.

searchDocs.title: A Brief History of Operating Systems
searchDocs.content: A Brief History of Operating Systems Many operating systems have been released. This is a timeline of some of the milestone events leading to some of the most prominent operating systems used today: - BeforeÂ theÂ mid-1960s:Â AÂ numberÂ ofÂ differentÂ manufacturersÂ producedÂ various computersÂ forÂ business.Â SinceÂ theseÂ machinesÂ wereÂ expensive,Â andÂ becauseÂ there wereÂ manyÂ differentÂ manufacturers,Â aÂ relativelyÂ smallÂ numberÂ ofÂ machinesÂ of eachÂ modelÂ wereÂ produced.Â VeryÂ littleÂ wasÂ standardized,Â andÂ dataÂ wasÂ rarely interchangedÂ betweenÂ computers.Â Consequently,Â thereÂ wereÂ manyÂ different operatingÂ systems,Â eachÂ withÂ aÂ fairlyÂ smallÂ market. - 1964/1965Â -Â MITÂ andÂ partnersÂ beginÂ theÂ MulticsÂ Project.Â ThisÂ project introducedÂ manyÂ conceptsÂ thatÂ becameÂ commonÂ inÂ laterÂ operatingÂ systems, includingÂ aÂ heirarchicalÂ filesystem,Â multitasking,Â andÂ interactiveÂ operation. ThisÂ projectÂ continuedÂ throughÂ 2000.Â However,Â MulticsÂ wasÂ aÂ fairly resource-intensiveÂ operatingÂ systemÂ andÂ ranÂ onlyÂ onÂ veryÂ specificÂ hardare. - 1969Â -Â BellÂ LabsÂ decidedÂ toÂ endÂ theirÂ participationÂ inÂ theÂ MulticsÂ project. DennisÂ RitchieÂ andÂ KenÂ Thompson,Â BellÂ LabsÂ employeesÂ whoÂ wereÂ familiarÂ with theÂ MulticsÂ project,Â decidedÂ toÂ implementÂ someÂ ofÂ itsÂ featuresÂ inÂ aÂ much lighter-weightÂ operatingÂ system,Â whichÂ theyÂ calledÂ Unix.Â UnixÂ wasÂ soon rewrittenÂ inÂ theÂ CÂ language,Â andÂ couldÂ beÂ fairlyÂ easilyÂ portedÂ toÂ other typesÂ ofÂ computers. - 1970sÂ -Â UnixÂ continuedÂ toÂ growÂ inÂ popularity.Â ManyÂ computerÂ vendors licensedÂ itÂ andÂ adaptedÂ itÂ toÂ workÂ withÂ theirÂ computers;Â someÂ ofÂ these variantsÂ includedÂ XenixÂ (Microsoft),Â AIXÂ (IBM),Â UltrixÂ (DigitalÂ Equipment Corporation),Â HP/UXÂ (HP),Â andÂ manyÂ others. - 1976Â -Â Microcomputers,Â 8-bitÂ computersÂ inexpensiveÂ enoughÂ toÂ beÂ purchased byÂ individualsÂ orÂ smallÂ businesses,Â becameÂ widelyÂ available. NeedingÂ anÂ operatingÂ system,Â IBMÂ contactedÂ MicrosoftÂ -Â butÂ theirÂ only operatingÂ systemÂ atÂ theÂ timeÂ wasÂ Xenix,Â andÂ theÂ IBMÂ PCÂ wasÂ notÂ powerful enoughÂ toÂ runÂ XenixÂ well,Â soÂ MicrosoftÂ licensedÂ (andÂ laterÂ purchased)Â aÂ CP/M cloneÂ namedÂ 86/DOSÂ (akaÂ QDOS)Â fromÂ aÂ localÂ computerÂ companyÂ (SeattleÂ Computer Products).Â ThisÂ operatingÂ systemÂ wasÂ usedÂ asÂ theÂ basisÂ forÂ Microsoft'sÂ DOS (diskÂ operatingÂ system)Â product,Â namedÂ PC/DOSÂ whenÂ marketedÂ byÂ IBMÂ orÂ MS/DOS whenÂ marketedÂ byÂ Microsoft. - 1983Â -Â TheÂ IBMÂ PCÂ wasÂ successfulÂ inÂ theÂ market,Â dueÂ toÂ bothÂ IBM'sÂ marketing andÂ theÂ factÂ thatÂ IBMÂ publishedÂ theÂ technicalÂ specificationsÂ whichÂ enabled otherÂ companiesÂ toÂ sellÂ compatibleÂ accessories,Â soÂ IBMÂ producedÂ moreÂ powerful modelsÂ includingÂ theÂ IBMÂ PC/XTÂ (1983)Â andÂ PC/ATÂ (1984).Â TheseÂ modelsÂ hadÂ much largerÂ amountsÂ ofÂ RAMÂ asÂ wellÂ asÂ hardÂ disks,Â soÂ MicrosoftÂ neededÂ toÂ update DOSÂ withÂ newÂ features;Â theyÂ didÂ thisÂ byÂ incorporatingÂ someÂ featuresÂ from XenixÂ (theirÂ UnixÂ version),Â includingÂ aÂ heirarchicalÂ filesystem. - TheÂ AndroidÂ platformÂ is basedÂ onÂ theÂ LinuxÂ kernel.

searchDocs.title: GUI vs CLI: Advantages and Disadvantages
searchDocs.content: GUI vs CLI: Advantages and Disadvantages Both graphical user interfaces (GUIs) and Command Line Interfaces (CLIs) have strengths and weaknesses, making them suited for different types of use. The visual nature of a graphical user interface makes it well-suited for creating, editing, and viewing visual media, such as photos, videos, presentations, and highly-formatted documents. A GUI is also well-suited to dense displays of visual information, such as data dashboards. However, many GUIs are not well-suited to automation, and the large amount of information in the display may consume a lot of network bandwidth if the GUI is used over a remote connection. On the other hand, a CLI is well-suited to task automation, and many tasks may require fewer steps to perform than when using a GUI. CLIs generall require much less bandwidth when used over a network, making them well-suited to remote administration tasks. To compare the data demands of the two types of user interfaces, consider the amount of information that needs to be sent to the display to update it: - AÂ GUIÂ onÂ aÂ 1920x1080Â ("fullÂ highÂ definition")Â monitorÂ displaysÂ about 6Â megabytesÂ ofÂ dataÂ (2Â millionÂ pixelsÂ xÂ 3Â bytesÂ perÂ pixel) - AÂ CLIÂ (orÂ TUI)Â onÂ anÂ 80x25Â characterÂ terminalÂ displaysÂ about 2Â kilobytesÂ ofÂ dataÂ (0.002Â megabytes)Â atÂ oneÂ time As an example of the strengths of each type of user interface, consider the task of croping, resizing, and changing the format of photographs: - AÂ GUIÂ immediatelyÂ showsÂ theÂ effectÂ ofÂ changesÂ andÂ allowsÂ the adjustmentsÂ toÂ beÂ easilyÂ fine-tuned,Â producingÂ exactÂ resultsÂ for aÂ small numberÂ ofÂ photos.Â However,Â itÂ mayÂ takeÂ manyÂ stepsÂ toÂ perform theÂ edits, soÂ editingÂ hundredsÂ ofÂ photographsÂ willÂ takeÂ aÂ veryÂ longÂ time. - AÂ CLIÂ isÂ well-suitedÂ toÂ automation.Â EditsÂ couldÂ beÂ appliedÂ toÂ hundreds ofÂ picturesÂ inÂ aÂ fewÂ seconds,Â ifÂ theÂ editsÂ canÂ beÂ adequatelyÂ describedÂ on theÂ command-line. A programmer will often use both types of user interfaces in combination. For example, they may adjust a sound file using a GUI, then use a CLI to place the sound file into a particular folder or directory. This is because programmer has been writing code to access the file, and it seems intuitive to use the same text-based reference to the file to manage the file.

searchDocs.title: What does an Operating System do?
1. Management and Separation of Resourcesâ€‹
searchDocs.pageTitle: What does an Operating System do?
searchDocs.content: Think of the specifications that were advertised when you bought your last computer (or smartphone):  multipleÂ CPUÂ coresseveralÂ gigabytesÂ ofÂ RAM memorystorageÂ inÂ theÂ gigabytes to terabytesÂ rangeaÂ displayÂ withÂ aÂ particularÂ resolutionvariousÂ peripherals,Â suchÂ asÂ cameras,Â speakers,Â andÂ soÂ forth  All of these are system resources. The operating system manages these resources to ensure that they are used effectively, and to ensure that there are no conflicts over their use.  As requested by the user(s), or as triggered by other factors such as the time of day or operational requirements, the OS will create processes -- running instances of computer programs. Each process is allocated compute resources by being permitted to run on one or more computer cores. To run a large number of processes, the OS will switch between them, stopping one process and starting another as needed to ensure that all of the processes get a fair share of system resources (which may not always be an equal share).  The operating system will allocate the available memory to processes and to the operating system's internal operations. The OS will program the system hardware to ensure that no process can overwrite memory allocated to another process.  The OS will also allocate storage space to various files as they are created and extended, and deallocate space when those files are truncated (shortened) or deleted. The space allocated to one file will be protected from use in other files.  Display space is similarly shared; the operating system will ensure that multiple programs can each display in their own windows, but prevent them from destroying graphics being displayed by other windows.  Peripheral devices are managed in different ways according to the characteristics of the device. For example, sound output from multiple processes will be combined for simultaneous output to the speakers (or other output devices). However, when a process accesses a printer, output from that processes is collected into a document, and the documents are queued for sequential printing, because simultaneous access would result in garbled output.

searchDocs.title: 2. Security Enforcementâ€‹
searchDocs.pageTitle: What does an Operating System do?
searchDocs.content: It's important to keep information private in some contexts, and to share information in other contexts. The operating system is responsible for enforcing security rules. For example, on a smartphone, a social media app shouldn't be able to access data from a banking app, and on a cloud server, one customer shouldn't be able to access another customer's data. However, multiple smartphone apps might be permitted to access a photo album, and a company employee might need to view a report generated on a server from multiple customers' data.  The operating system is responsible for enforcing the security rules but not for creating them -- the system administrators and/or users are responsible for creating and maintaining the security settings and policies which the operating system enforces.

searchDocs.title: 3. Hardware Abstractionâ€‹
searchDocs.pageTitle: What does an Operating System do?
searchDocs.content: There are many different types of devices that perform similar functions, and multiple ways that these devices can be connected. For example:  AÂ keyboardÂ mayÂ beÂ connectedÂ viaÂ aÂ USBÂ connectionÂ orÂ aÂ wirelessÂ Bluetooth connection,Â orÂ mayÂ beÂ createdÂ asÂ aÂ virtualÂ keyboardÂ onÂ aÂ touchscreen.AÂ mouseÂ mayÂ beÂ connectedÂ viaÂ aÂ wiredÂ USB,Â wirelessÂ USBÂ dongle,Â or wirelessÂ BluetoothÂ connection.Â ButÂ thereÂ areÂ alsoÂ otherÂ typesÂ ofÂ devices whichÂ canÂ provideÂ theÂ sameÂ capabilityÂ ofÂ allowingÂ theÂ userÂ toÂ interact withÂ theÂ display,Â includingÂ trackpads,Â trackballs,Â andÂ touchscreens.SoundÂ mayÂ beÂ playedÂ overÂ built-inÂ speakers,Â anÂ externalÂ analogÂ speaker, anÂ analogÂ headset,Â aÂ digitalÂ speakerÂ orÂ headsetÂ withÂ aÂ USBÂ connection, aÂ BluetoothÂ speaker,Â earbuds,Â orÂ headset,Â orÂ playedÂ throughÂ aÂ television connectedÂ viaÂ HDMI.  The operating system abstracts away these hardware details. This means that programs can access devices in a general way without having to be programmed to individually deal with each type of device that may be used. This enables a program to request keyboard input or play sounds without regard to the details of the specific hardware available.

searchDocs.title: 4. Maintaining the Programming Modelâ€‹
searchDocs.pageTitle: What does an Operating System do?
searchDocs.content: The operating system, computer hardware, and development tools (compiler, linker, and so forth) work together to present the "programming model" -- a conceptual framework which software developers use when creating software.  As a simple example, several different application program may be designed to occupy the same area of memory; obviously, this presents a conflict when these applications are used at the same time, so the operating system works with the computer's hardware to load the applications into different areas of physical memory, and then use the computer's virtual memory capabilities to make each program appear to be loaded into the region of memory for which it was written.

searchDocs.title: What is an Operating System?
searchDocs.content: What is an Operating System? An operating system (OS) does exactly what the name states: It is software that operates a computer system! Not all computers have had or required an operating system. Particularly simple computers, including the earliest models of both business computers and microcomputers, as well as very simple embedded computers, do not require an operating system. The computer embedded into a simple mass-market microwave oven, for example, only ever runs one program, does not have communications capabilities, does not multitask, and is never updated, and therefore has no operating system. However, virtually all contemporary computer systems, including embedded devices, are sufficiently complex that they are equipped with an operating system.

searchDocs.title: Viewing Online Documentation
searchDocs.content: Viewing Online Documentation To find a Linux command to perform a particular function, use theapropos or man -k commands to search the online documentation. For example, to see commands related to "calendar": apropos calendar man -k calendar # same as the above! To view information about a Linux command, use the online manual ("manpages"), accessed with the man command: man commandname For example, to view the online manual page for cp, enter the command: man cp On Windows, you can see a list of commonly used commands by typing help To view information about a Windows command, use the online help: help commandname For example, to view the online help for dir, enter the command: help dir Alternately, to get a brief help summary for a command, enter the name of the command followed by /? -- for example, to get a help summary for the copy command, type copy /?

searchDocs.title: Access Control Lists
searchDocs.content: Access Control Lists Windows and Linux both offer File Access Control Lists (FACLs or ACLs) to provide fine-grained control of file access. ACLs allow individual file permissions to be granted or denied to individual users and groups. However, the management of ACLs can be a complicated subject, and even experienced users sometimes misconfigure ACLs! Due to this complexity, we will not be covering ACLs in this introductory course. However, on a Windows system, basic manipulation of ACLs can be performed using the Windows Explorer file manager. Select a file which is stored on an NTFS filesystem (most internal hard disks or solid state disks, but not external drives) and right-click on it to view the file's Properties. Select the Security tab on the dialog that is displayed to view the users for which ACLs have been created, and the basic permissions that have been allowed or denied for that user on the selected file. Note that the effective permission will be a combination of the permissions allowed/denied on the file as well as on the parent directories.

searchDocs.title: Default Text Editorsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: It is useful to learn how to use the text editor(s) provided by default with each operating system, because these editors will be available on almost any computer you use without installing any additional software. In other words, you'll be able to confidently walk up to any system, anywhere, and edit a file!

searchDocs.title: Linux Default Text Editorâ€‹
searchDocs.content: On Linux systems, most distributions (the organizations or companies responsible for maintaining and distributing the system) have standardized on the nano editor as the default CLI/TUI text editor (replacing the less-user-friendly but more-powerful vi editor). To start nano, type nano and optionally provide a filename:  nano nano file   Nano provides a help display at the bottom of the screen. The carat ^ symbol indicates the control key, so the help text "^X Exit" means that you would press Ctrl-X to exit from the editor.  Since Linux systems provide multiple desktop GUI environments, the default GUI text editor(s) will vary with the installed desktop GUI. For example, on Linux desktops using the Gnome environment, the default GUI text editor is Gedit or Gnome Text Editor; on Linux desktops using the KDE desktop, the default GUI text editor is a program called Kate.

searchDocs.title: Windows Default Text Editorâ€‹
searchDocs.content: The current versions of Windows (Windows 10 & 11) do not provide a CLI/TUI text editor (previous versions of Windows did provide a CLI text editor, and there is a current discussion about ading this back in). However, you can run the GUI Notepad editor, either from the Start Menu, or from the command line (as long as you are not accessing the Windows system remotely through a non-graphical connection), optionally providing a filename to be edited:  notepad notepadÂ file

searchDocs.title: Other Text Editorsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: There are many other text editors available for both platforms, and many editors are available that work on multiple operating systems. For example, nano and vi are available for Windows systems, and editors similar to notepad are available on Linux.  There are also several categories of software that are (arguably) a type of text editor, including:  BasicÂ textÂ editorsCodeÂ editors,Â forÂ editingÂ softwareÂ andÂ configurationÂ files,Â withÂ features suchÂ asÂ tooltipÂ help,Â syntaxÂ highlighting,Â bracketÂ matching,Â andÂ automaticÂ indentationWordÂ processors,Â forÂ editingÂ documents,Â withÂ featuresÂ suchÂ asÂ spell checking,Â visualÂ formatting,Â advancedÂ layoutÂ featuresÂ suchÂ asÂ columns andÂ tables  Software developers and system administrators have strong opinions about their tools, and particularly about their text editors. Things to consider when selecting any type of text editor include:  -Â Interface:Â doesÂ theÂ editorÂ useÂ aÂ graphicalÂ userÂ interface,Â aÂ textÂ userÂ interface,Â orÂ canÂ itÂ operateÂ inÂ bothÂ modes? -Â Tools:Â doesÂ theÂ editorÂ haveÂ usefulÂ toolsÂ suchÂ asÂ syntaxÂ highlightingÂ forÂ commonÂ languagesÂ andÂ configurationÂ files?Â DoesÂ theÂ listÂ ofÂ supportedÂ languagesÂ includeÂ theÂ onesÂ youÂ wantÂ toÂ use? -Â VisualÂ complexity:Â someÂ usersÂ preferÂ anÂ editorÂ withÂ on-screenÂ controlsÂ (orÂ help)Â forÂ mostÂ orÂ allÂ ofÂ theÂ actionsÂ theyÂ mayÂ performÂ soÂ thatÂ theyÂ canÂ accessÂ theseÂ featuresÂ quickly.Â OthersÂ preferÂ aÂ less-clutteredÂ screenÂ whichÂ dedicatesÂ maximumÂ screenÂ spaceÂ toÂ contentÂ andÂ minimizesÂ distractions. -Â PreviewsÂ andÂ integrationÂ withÂ otherÂ tools:Â canÂ theÂ softwareÂ provideÂ visualÂ previews,Â suchÂ asÂ HTMLÂ andÂ CSSÂ displayÂ forÂ webÂ documents,Â LaTeXÂ rendering,Â andÂ accessibilityÂ assessments?Â CanÂ youÂ directlyÂ invokeÂ publishing,Â contentÂ conversion,Â fileÂ transfer,Â orÂ compilationÂ processesÂ fromÂ withinÂ theÂ editor? -Â FeatureÂ control:Â canÂ youÂ easilyÂ turnÂ featuresÂ onÂ andÂ off?Â ForÂ example,Â canÂ youÂ disableÂ spellÂ checkingÂ orÂ syntaxÂ highlightingÂ ifÂ yourÂ fileÂ containsÂ aÂ sectionÂ thatÂ isÂ inÂ aÂ differentÂ language?Â CanÂ youÂ disableÂ auto-correctionÂ whenÂ itÂ isÂ notÂ relevantÂ toÂ theÂ projectÂ atÂ hand?  Most software developers and system administrators use multiple editors for different tasks - for example, they may choose one editor for quick cnfiguration changes, another editor (or IDE) for larger development tasks, and multiple editors for different types of documentation.  Note that features intended for one editing task can be a nuscience in another context. For example, a word processor will often convert double quote characters into "smart quotes" (look closely at the quotation characters in this line), where the opening and closing quote characters are distinct characters. While these look great and are good for general writing, they are problematic in code and in examples that may appear in documentation, because they will be rejected by some types of software which expect straight double-quotes (such as most shells).

searchDocs.title: Discretionary versus Mandatory Access Controls
searchDocs.content: Discretionary versus Mandatory Access Controls In multi-user operating systems it is important to be able to control access to information. This is usually done at the file and directory levels. There are two broad categories of access controls applied to files and directories: 1.Â DiscretionaryÂ AccessÂ ControlsÂ (DACs)Â -Â theseÂ areÂ accessÂ controlsÂ that canÂ beÂ setÂ toÂ anyÂ valueÂ atÂ theÂ discretionÂ ofÂ theÂ usersÂ orÂ administrators ofÂ theÂ computerÂ system. 2. MandatoryÂ AccessÂ ControlsÂ (MACs)Â -Â theseÂ areÂ accessÂ controlsÂ that areÂ appliedÂ acrossÂ theÂ entireÂ systemÂ inÂ aÂ uniformÂ way,Â andÂ cannotÂ be individuallyÂ overriddenÂ byÂ theÂ usersÂ orÂ administrators.Â AnÂ exampleÂ of aÂ MandatoryÂ AccessÂ ControlÂ systemÂ isÂ SELinuxÂ (security-enhancedÂ Linux), aÂ systemÂ originallyÂ developedÂ byÂ theÂ NationalÂ SecurityÂ AgencyÂ ofÂ the USÂ FederalÂ GovernmentÂ andÂ nowÂ partÂ ofÂ theÂ LinuxÂ Kernel (viaÂ KSMÂ -Â KernelÂ SecurityÂ Modules).Â SELinuxÂ usesÂ typeÂ enforcement andÂ labellingÂ ofÂ bothÂ resourcesÂ (suchÂ asÂ filesÂ andÂ networkÂ connections) andÂ processesÂ (runningÂ programs)Â toÂ determineÂ whetherÂ aÂ specificÂ process shouldÂ haveÂ accessÂ toÂ aÂ specificÂ resource,Â andÂ toÂ denyÂ accessÂ whenÂ itÂ doesÂ not. SELinuxÂ isÂ usedÂ inÂ severalÂ operatingÂ systems,Â includingÂ Android,Â Fedora, CentOS,Â andÂ RedÂ HatÂ EnterpriseÂ Linux. In this OPS102 course, we will be looking only at DACs.
