searchDocs.title: Regular Expression Dialects
searchDocs.content: Regular Expression Dialects Regular expressions have evolved over the years, and the various tools that handle regular expressions have different capabilities and slightly different syntax. In particular, the original Unix search tool grep came in three varieties: fgrep,Â whichÂ couldÂ searchÂ onlyÂ forÂ fixedÂ textÂ patternsgrep,Â whichÂ handledÂ basicÂ regularÂ expressionsegrep,Â whichÂ handledÂ anÂ extendedÂ formÂ ofÂ regularÂ expressions The GNU project originally shipped all three commands, but fgrep and egrep were never fully standardized, so they were removed from the Posix standard in 2001. They were recently also removed from the GNU project. Unlike the original Unix grep, the GNU grep can handle the full extended regular expression syntax, in either of two ways: ToÂ useÂ theÂ specialÂ charactersÂ (calledÂ "meta-characters") preceedÂ themÂ withÂ aÂ backslash.Â InÂ otherÂ words,Â whileÂ aÂ backslashÂ makes specialÂ charactersÂ likeÂ .Â orÂ ordinary,Â itÂ alsoÂ makesÂ ordinary charactersÂ intoÂ specialÂ characters. Alternately,Â useÂ theÂ -EÂ optionÂ toÂ makeÂ grepÂ understandÂ extended regularÂ expressions,Â whichÂ causesÂ metacharacters toÂ becomeÂ specialÂ characters. Other tools, such as sed, similarly require backslashes in front of some of the extended regexp meta-characters (or, if you're using a GNU version of sed, you can use the -E option to enable extended regular expressions, just like GNU grep). The Perl language introduced one of the most powerful and consistent versions of the regular expression language. There has been increasing consensus around "Perl-Compatible Regular Extensions" (aka PCRE) and that dialect is available in many tools (including GNU grep via the -Poption, as well as the PCRE/PCRE2 library for C and C++ programs, which is used in many software packages including Safari and Apache httpd).

searchDocs.title: Standard File Descriptors/Handles
searchDocs.content: Standard File Descriptors/Handles On Linux, other Unix-like systems, and on Windows, programs may openfile descriptors (Linux terminology) or file handles(Windows terminology). Each file descriptor/handle is a numbered channel connected to a file or device. By default, three channels are opened automatically by the shell when a process is started. These are: 0Â -Â StandardÂ InputÂ (stdin)Â -Â thisÂ isÂ theÂ defaultÂ inputÂ channelÂ for theÂ program 1Â -Â StandardÂ OutputÂ (stdout)Â -Â thisÂ isÂ theÂ defaultÂ outputÂ channel forÂ theÂ program,Â usedÂ toÂ outputÂ "normal"Â messages 2Â -Â StandardÂ ErrorÂ (stderr)Â -Â thisÂ isÂ theÂ defaultÂ errorÂ channel forÂ theÂ program,Â usedÂ toÂ outputÂ errorÂ messages Without redirection, all three of these descriptors/handles are connected to the terminal. Therefore, the command will get input from the terminal, send output messages to the terminal, and send error messages to the terminal.

searchDocs.title: The Seven Basic Elements of Regular Expressions
Charactersâ€‹
searchDocs.pageTitle: The Seven Basic Elements of Regular Expressions
searchDocs.content: In a regular expression (regexp), any character that doesn't otherwise have a special meaning matches that character. So the digit "5", for example, matches the digit "5"; similarly "cat" matches the letters "c", "a", and "t" in sequence.  A backslash can be used to remove any special meaning which a character has. The period character "." is a type of wildcard (see below), so to search for a literal period, we place a backslash in front of it:"\."

searchDocs.title: Wildcardsâ€‹
searchDocs.pageTitle: The Seven Basic Elements of Regular Expressions
searchDocs.content: A period "." will match any single character. Similarly, three periods "\...\" will match any three characters.

searchDocs.title: Bracket Expressions / Character Classesâ€‹
searchDocs.pageTitle: The Seven Basic Elements of Regular Expressions
searchDocs.content: Bracket Expressions or Character Classes are contained in square brackets "[ ]"  AÂ listÂ ofÂ charactersÂ inÂ squareÂ bracketsÂ willÂ matchÂ anyÂ oneÂ characterÂ from theÂ listÂ ofÂ characters:Â "[abc]"Â willÂ matchÂ "a",Â "b",Â orÂ "c" AÂ rangeÂ ofÂ charactersÂ inÂ squareÂ brackets,Â writtenÂ asÂ aÂ startingÂ character,Â a dash,Â andÂ anÂ endingÂ character,Â willÂ matchÂ anyÂ characterÂ inÂ that range: the regular expression "[0-9]"Â willÂ matchÂ anyÂ oneÂ digit. ThereÂ areÂ someÂ pre-definedÂ namedÂ characterÂ classes.Â TheseÂ areÂ selectedÂ by specifyingÂ theÂ nameÂ ofÂ theÂ characterÂ classÂ surroundedÂ byÂ colonsÂ andÂ square brackets,Â placedÂ withinÂ outerÂ squareÂ brackets,Â likeÂ "[[:digits:]]". TheÂ availableÂ namesÂ are: alnumÂ -Â alphanumericalphaÂ -Â alphabeticÂ charactersblankÂ -Â horizontalÂ whitespaceÂ (space,Â tab)cntrlÂ -Â controlÂ characters (text codes that don't print, such as newline, tab, and bell)digitÂ -Â digitsgraphÂ -Â letters,Â digits,Â andÂ punctuationprintÂ -Â letters,Â digits,Â punctuation,Â andÂ spacepunctÂ -Â punctuationÂ marksspaceÂ -Â horizontalÂ andÂ verticalÂ whitespaceÂ (space,Â tab,Â verticalÂ tab, formÂ feed)upperÂ -Â UPPERCASEÂ letterslowerÂ -Â lowercaseÂ lettersxdigitÂ -Â hexidecimalÂ digitsÂ (digitsÂ plusÂ a-fÂ andÂ A-F) Ranges,Â lists,Â andÂ namedÂ characterÂ classesÂ mayÂ beÂ combinedÂ - e.g.,Â "[[[:digit:]]+-.,]"Â "[[:digit:]][:punct:]]"Â "[0-9_*]" ToÂ invertÂ aÂ characterÂ class,Â addÂ aÂ caratÂ ^Â characterÂ asÂ theÂ firstÂ character afterÂ theÂ openingÂ squareÂ bracket:Â "[^[:digit:]]"Â matchesÂ anyÂ non-digit character,Â andÂ "[^:]"Â matchesÂ anyÂ characterÂ thatÂ isÂ notÂ aÂ colon. ToÂ includeÂ aÂ literalÂ carat,Â placeÂ itÂ atÂ theÂ endÂ ofÂ theÂ characterÂ class. ToÂ includeÂ aÂ literalÂ dashÂ orÂ closingÂ squareÂ bracket,Â placeÂ itÂ atÂ theÂ start ofÂ theÂ characterÂ class.

searchDocs.title: Repetitionâ€‹
searchDocs.pageTitle: The Seven Basic Elements of Regular Expressions
searchDocs.content: AÂ repeatÂ countÂ canÂ beÂ placedÂ inÂ curlyÂ brackets.Â ItÂ appliesÂ toÂ theÂ previous element: "x{3}"Â matchesÂ "xxx"AÂ repeatÂ canÂ beÂ aÂ range,Â writtenÂ asÂ min,maxÂ inÂ curlyÂ brackets:Â "x{2,5}" willÂ matchÂ "xx",Â "xxx",Â "xxxx",Â orÂ "xxxxx"TheÂ maximumÂ valueÂ inÂ aÂ rangeÂ canÂ beÂ omitted:Â "x{2,}"Â willÂ matchÂ twoÂ or moreÂ "x"Â charactersÂ inÂ aÂ rowThereÂ areÂ shortÂ formsÂ forÂ someÂ commonly-usedÂ ranges: "*"Â isÂ theÂ sameÂ asÂ "{0,}"Â (zeroÂ orÂ more)"+"Â isÂ theÂ sameÂ asÂ "{1,}"Â (oneÂ orÂ more)"?"Â isÂ theÂ sameÂ asÂ "{0,1}"Â (zeroÂ orÂ one)

searchDocs.title: Alternationâ€‹
searchDocs.pageTitle: The Seven Basic Elements of Regular Expressions
searchDocs.content: TheÂ verticalÂ barÂ indicatesÂ alternationÂ -Â eitherÂ theÂ expressionÂ onÂ the leftÂ orÂ theÂ rightÂ canÂ beÂ matched:Â *"hot|cold"*Â willÂ matchÂ *"hot"* orÂ *"cold"`*

searchDocs.title: Groupingâ€‹
searchDocs.pageTitle: The Seven Basic Elements of Regular Expressions
searchDocs.content: ElementsÂ placedÂ inÂ parenthesisÂ areÂ treatedÂ asÂ aÂ group,Â andÂ canÂ beÂ repeated:"(na)* batman"Â willÂ matchÂ "nananana batman"Â andÂ "nananananananana batman"GroupingÂ mayÂ alsoÂ beÂ usedÂ toÂ limitÂ alternation:Â "(fire|green)house"Â will matchÂ "firehouse"Â andÂ "greenhouse"

searchDocs.title: Anchorsâ€‹
searchDocs.pageTitle: The Seven Basic Elements of Regular Expressions
searchDocs.content: AnchorsÂ matchÂ locations,Â notÂ characters.AÂ caratÂ symbolÂ willÂ matchÂ theÂ startÂ ofÂ aÂ line:Â "^[[:upper:]]"Â wilÂ match linesÂ thatÂ startÂ withÂ anÂ uppercaseÂ letter.AÂ dollarÂ signÂ willÂ matchÂ theÂ endÂ ofÂ aÂ line:Â "[[:punct:]]$"Â willÂ match linesÂ thatÂ endÂ withÂ aÂ punctuationÂ mark.TheÂ twoÂ anchorsÂ mayÂ beÂ usedÂ together:Â "cat"Â willÂ matchÂ theÂ wordÂ "cat"anywhereÂ onÂ aÂ line,Â butÂ "^cat$"Â willÂ onlyÂ matchÂ linesÂ thatÂ containÂ justtheÂ wordÂ "cat"Â andÂ nothingÂ else.Â Similarly,Â "^[[0-9.]]$"Â willÂ matchÂ lines thatÂ areÂ madeÂ upÂ ofÂ onlyÂ digitsÂ andÂ dotÂ characters,Â andÂ "^...$"*Â or "^.3$"`Â willÂ onlyÂ matchÂ linesÂ thatÂ containÂ exactlyÂ threeÂ characters.

searchDocs.title: Piping
searchDocs.content: Piping Piping is a special case of redirection, where the output (stdout) of one command is connected to the input (stdin) of another command. This is set up using the vertical-bar (pipe) symbol: | (this may look like a solid or a dashed vertical line, depending on the terminal font in use). For example, on Windows, the output of the help command is more than one screen long. You could pipe the output of the help command into the input of the more command to view one screen of text at a time: >Â help|more ForÂ moreÂ informationÂ onÂ aÂ specificÂ command,Â typeÂ HELPÂ command-name ASSOC DisplaysÂ orÂ modifiesÂ fileÂ extensionÂ associations. ATTRIB DisplaysÂ orÂ changesÂ fileÂ attributes. BREAK SetsÂ orÂ clearsÂ extendedÂ CTRL+CÂ checking. BCDEDIT SetsÂ propertiesÂ inÂ bootÂ databaseÂ toÂ controlÂ bootÂ loading. CACLS DisplaysÂ orÂ modifiesÂ accessÂ controlÂ listsÂ (ACLs)Â ofÂ files. CALL CallsÂ oneÂ batchÂ programÂ fromÂ another. CD DisplaysÂ theÂ nameÂ ofÂ orÂ changesÂ theÂ currentÂ directory. CHCP DisplaysÂ orÂ setsÂ theÂ activeÂ codeÂ pageÂ number. CHDIR DisplaysÂ theÂ nameÂ ofÂ orÂ changesÂ theÂ currentÂ directory. CHKDSK ChecksÂ aÂ diskÂ andÂ displaysÂ aÂ statusÂ report. CHKNTFS DisplaysÂ orÂ modifiesÂ theÂ checkingÂ ofÂ diskÂ atÂ bootÂ time. CLS ClearsÂ theÂ screen. CMD StartsÂ aÂ newÂ instanceÂ ofÂ theÂ WindowsÂ commandÂ interpreter. COLOR SetsÂ theÂ defaultÂ consoleÂ foregroundÂ andÂ backgroundÂ colors. COMP ComparesÂ theÂ contentsÂ ofÂ twoÂ filesÂ orÂ setsÂ ofÂ files. COMPACT DisplaysÂ orÂ altersÂ theÂ compressionÂ ofÂ filesÂ onÂ NTFSÂ partitions. CONVERT ConvertsÂ FATÂ volumesÂ toÂ NTFS. YouÂ cannotÂ convertÂ the currentÂ drive. --Â More -- Press the ENTER key to scroll by one line, the spacebar to scroll by one screen, or "q" to quit. Similarly, on Linux, a long directory listing could be redirected tomore, or better yet, the improved less command: $Â lsÂ -lÂ /etcÂ |Â less totalÂ 2160 drwxr-xr-x. 3Â rootÂ root 4096Â JunÂ 29Â 20:00Â abrt -rw-r--r--. 1Â rootÂ root 18Â MayÂ 30Â 03:03Â adjtime -rw-r--r--. 1Â rootÂ root 1529Â NovÂ 27 2022Â aliases drwxr-xr-x. 2Â rootÂ root 4096Â MayÂ 30Â 09:32Â alliance drwxr-xr-x. 3Â rootÂ root 4096Â Sep 3Â 20:00Â alsa drwxr-xr-x. 2Â rootÂ root 4096Â Aug 9Â 09:01Â alternatives drwxr-xr-x. 4Â rootÂ root 4096Â AprÂ 13Â 17:47Â anaconda -rw-r--r--. 1Â rootÂ root 541Â JanÂ 18 2023Â anacrontab -rw-r--r--. 1Â rootÂ root 269Â JanÂ 17 2023Â anthy-unicode.conf -rw-r--r--. 1Â rootÂ root 833Â FebÂ 10 2023Â appstream.conf -rw-r--r--. 1Â rootÂ root 55Â Sep 3Â 20:00Â asound.conf -rw-r--r--. 1Â rootÂ root 1Â JanÂ 17 2023Â at.deny drwxr-x---. 4Â rootÂ root 4096Â Aug 5Â 20:00Â audit drwxr-xr-x. 3Â rootÂ root 4096Â MayÂ 30Â 03:03Â authselect drwxr-xr-x. 4Â rootÂ root 4096Â MarÂ 18 2023Â avahi drwxr-xr-x. 2Â rootÂ root 4096Â MayÂ 30Â 09:33Â avrdude drwxr-xr-x. 2Â rootÂ root 4096Â Aug 8Â 10:57Â bash_completion.d -rw-r--r--. 1Â rootÂ root 2638Â NovÂ 27 2022Â bashrc -rw-r--r--. 1Â rootÂ root 535Â Aug 6Â 20:00Â bindresvport.blacklist drwxr-xr-x. 2Â rootÂ root 4096Â SepÂ 17Â 20:00Â binfmt.d drwxr-xr-x. 2Â rootÂ root 4096Â AugÂ 24Â 20:00Â bluetooth drwxr-xr-x. 2Â rootÂ root 4096Â MayÂ 30Â 09:32Â bonobo-activation : Like more, you can press ENTER to scroll by one line or SPACE to scroll by one screen, or "q" to quit; but you can also use the up/down arrow keys, or the PgUp/PgDn keys, to scroll in either direction by one line or one screen. searchDocs.title: Permission Communitiesâ€‹
searchDocs.content: There are three communities of users for each file:  UserÂ --Â theÂ oneÂ userÂ thatÂ ownsÂ theÂ file  GroupÂ --Â theÂ groupÂ ofÂ usersÂ thatÂ ownsÂ theÂ file  OtherÂ --Â everyÂ otherÂ userÂ ofÂ theÂ computerÂ system  These communitities are presented in this order, so remember the sequence!: User - Group - Other (u g o)  Note that each file has both an individual user and a group owner. Thels -l command shows the user and group owner in the third and fourth columns of output.

searchDocs.title: Permissionsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Each community has three **permissions** for each file which may be individually turned on or off:  ReadÂ --Â theÂ abilityÂ toÂ readÂ aÂ file.  WriteÂ --Â theÂ abilityÂ toÂ writeÂ toÂ theÂ file,Â includingÂ permissionÂ to addÂ to,Â change,Â orÂ truncateÂ (shorten)Â theÂ file.  eXecuteÂ --Â theÂ abilityÂ toÂ runÂ (execute)Â aÂ file.  Remember this sequence also!: Read - Write - eXecute (r w x)  When applied to directories, these permissions are interpreted differently:  ReadÂ --Â theÂ abilityÂ toÂ seeÂ theÂ namesÂ ofÂ theÂ filesÂ andÂ subdirectories withinÂ theÂ directory.Â ThisÂ isÂ alsoÂ calledÂ "search"Â permission.  WriteÂ --Â theÂ abilityÂ toÂ create/delete/renameÂ filesÂ andÂ subdirectories withinÂ theÂ directory.  eXecuteÂ (access)Â --Â theÂ abilityÂ toÂ accessÂ filesÂ withÂ theÂ directory. IfÂ turnedÂ off,Â theÂ filesÂ cannotÂ beÂ accessed,Â andÂ metadataÂ aboutÂ eachÂ file (suchÂ asÂ theÂ owner,Â groupÂ owner,Â fileÂ length,Â permissions,Â andÂ timestamps) cannotÂ beÂ accessedÂ either.Â YouÂ canÂ thinkÂ ofÂ thisÂ asÂ accessÂ permission whenÂ appliedÂ toÂ directories.Â ThisÂ isÂ sometimesÂ calledÂ passthrough permission.  If execute permission is enabled for a directory but read permission has not been enabled, the affected community cannot view a directory listing to determine filenames, but if they know the name of a file within that directory, they may still access it.  If read permission is enabled for a directory but execute permission has not been enabled, the affected community can view the names of files in a directory (but only the names, not permissions, file size, ownership, or any other information), but they will have no access to use the files in any way.  However, read and execute permission are almost always assigned to a directory together.  In order to access a file, a user must have execute permission on __all__ of the directories from the root directory to the directory containing the file. For example, on the file/home/jdoe/ops102/practice/info.txt, a user must have execute permission on all four directories (home, jdoe, ops102, practice) to access the file.

searchDocs.title: Viewing Permissionsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Permissions may be viewed with the ls -l command (the ls command with the -l "long detailed listing" option). For example:  $Â lsÂ -lÂ /etc/hosts -rw-r--r--.Â 1Â rootÂ rootÂ 386Â NovÂ 27 2022Â /etc/hosts   Notice that the file's owner is "root", and the file's group owner is also "root".  The first character on this line is the file type ("-" meaning a regular file), and the next nine characters represent the three communities, each having three permissions. The permissions are written as a letter -- "r", "w", or "x" -- if the permission is enabled, or a dash "-" if the permission is disabled. Therefore, in the example above:  rw- theÂ userÂ whoÂ ownsÂ theÂ fileÂ hasÂ readÂ andÂ writeÂ permission r-- theÂ groupÂ thatÂ ownsÂ theÂ fileÂ hasÂ readÂ permission r-- othersÂ haveÂ readÂ permission   Note that the user who owns the file is listed as root and the group that owns the file is listed as root -- these are not the same! The user account and group happen to have the same name in this case.  To view the permisions on a directory, you may need to specify the -doption to the ls command, which causes it to display the specified directory instead of the contents of that directory. searchDocs.title: Setting Permissionsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: The permissions on a file are also called the permission mode of the file, so the command to change the permissions is called chmod("change mode").  The chmod command can be used in either of two ways: with symbolic or numeric permissions.  In either case, the command accepts the mode as the first positional argument, and the filename(s) (or patterns) as the remaining positional arguments:  chmod mode filename...

searchDocs.title: Using Symbolic Modeâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Symbolic mode represents permissions as a list of one or more communities, represented by a letter:  uÂ (user) gÂ (group) oÂ (other) aÂ (allÂ -Â aÂ shortÂ formÂ toÂ specifyÂ ugo)   This is followed by an action symbol:  +Â (addÂ permissions) -Â (removeÂ permissions) =Â (setÂ permissions)   The difference between +/- and = is that +/- will add or remove the specified permissions while leaving other permissions unchanged, while = will explicitly set the permissions to exactly the value specified.  This is followed by zero or more of these letters, representing permissions:  rÂ (read)`\ wÂ (write)`\ xÂ (executeÂ -Â noteÂ thatÂ thisÂ isÂ lowercase)`\ XÂ (executeÂ ifÂ appliedÂ toÂ aÂ directory,Â orÂ nothingÂ ifÂ appliedÂ toÂ aÂ file --Â noteÂ thatÂ thisÂ isÂ UPPERCASE)   Therefore the symbolic notation g+rx instructs chmod to add read and execute permission to the group community, and a-w instructs chmod to remote write permission from all of the communities (user, group, and other).  Here is an example:  $Â touchÂ test001 #Â createÂ aÂ fileÂ forÂ testing $Â lsÂ -lÂ test001 #Â showÂ theÂ currentÂ permissions -rw-r--r--.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 0Â SepÂ 26Â 11:20Â test001 $Â chmodÂ g+wÂ test001 #Â toÂ group,Â addÂ (+)Â writeÂ permission $Â lsÂ -lÂ test001 -rw-rw-r--.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 0Â SepÂ 26Â 11:20Â test001 $Â chmodÂ o-rÂ test001 #Â toÂ other,Â removeÂ (-)Â readÂ permission $Â lsÂ -lÂ test001 -rw-rw----.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 0Â SepÂ 26Â 11:20Â test001 $Â chmodÂ u=rw,go=Â test001Â #Â setÂ userÂ toÂ haveÂ onlyÂ readÂ andÂ write,Â groupÂ andÂ otherÂ toÂ haveÂ nothing $Â lsÂ -lÂ test001 -rw-------.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 0Â SepÂ 26Â 11:20Â test001   And another example using a directory:  $Â mkdirÂ apple #Â createÂ aÂ directoryÂ forÂ testing $Â touchÂ apple/honeycrisp #Â createÂ someÂ filesÂ inÂ thatÂ directory $Â touchÂ apple/gala $Â touchÂ apple/ambrosia $Â lsÂ -lÂ -dÂ apple #Â seeÂ theÂ permissionsÂ onÂ theÂ directory drwxr-xr-x.Â 2Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 100Â SepÂ 26Â 11:26Â apple $Â lsÂ -lÂ apple #Â seeÂ theÂ files totalÂ 0 -rw-r--r--.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 0Â SepÂ 26Â 11:26Â ambrosia -rw-r--r--.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 0Â SepÂ 26Â 11:25Â gala -rw-r--r--.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 0Â SepÂ 26Â 11:25Â honeycrisp $Â chmodÂ a=rxÂ apple #Â setÂ permissionÂ (forÂ all)Â toÂ readÂ andÂ executeÂ only $Â lsÂ -lÂ -dÂ apple dr-xr-xr-x.Â 2Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 100Â SepÂ 26Â 11:26Â apple $Â lsÂ -lÂ apple #Â noteÂ thatÂ weÂ canÂ stillÂ seeÂ insideÂ theÂ directory totalÂ 0 -rw-r--r--.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 0Â SepÂ 26Â 11:26Â ambrosia -rw-r--r--.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 0Â SepÂ 26Â 11:25Â gala -rw-r--r--.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 0Â SepÂ 26Â 11:25Â honeycrisp $Â touchÂ apple/macintosh #Â weÂ cannotÂ createÂ aÂ fileÂ inÂ theÂ directory touch:Â cannotÂ touchÂ 'apple/macintosh':Â PermissionÂ denied $Â mvÂ apple/galaÂ apple/fujiÂ #Â weÂ cannotÂ renameÂ aÂ file mv:Â cannotÂ moveÂ 'apple/gala'Â toÂ 'apple/fuji':Â PermissionÂ denied $Â rmÂ apple/gala #Â weÂ cannotÂ removeÂ aÂ file searchDocs.title: Using Numeric Modeâ€‹
searchDocs.content: You can also specify a mode using a number. Each digit has a range of 0 to 7, so these are known as octal (base eight) numbers. An extra zero is often written in front of the number to indicate that the number is in octal.  When a numeric value is used to specify the permission mode, all of the permissions for all of the communities must be set at the same time. You cannot add or remove some permissions, or set permission for just some of the communities, as you can with symbolic mode.  The digits are written from left-to-right in the order of the communities (u g o), with each digit being the sum of the granted permission according to these values:  4Â read 2Â write 1Â execute   Examples:  rwxÂ wouldÂ haveÂ aÂ valueÂ ofÂ 7Â (4+2+1) rw-Â wouldÂ haveÂ aÂ valueÂ ofÂ 6Â (4+2) r--Â wouldÂ haveÂ aÂ valueÂ ofÂ 4Â (4)   Therefore these permissions are equivalent:  rwxrw-r--Â 0764 rwxrwxrwxÂ 0777 rw-r--r--Â 0744 rwx--x--xÂ 0711   Here are some examples of chmod commands with numeric modes:  $Â touchÂ example001 $Â lsÂ -lÂ example001 -rw-r--r--.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 0Â SepÂ 26Â 11:45Â example001 $Â chmodÂ 0111Â example001 $Â lsÂ -lÂ example001 ---x--x--x.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 0Â SepÂ 26Â 11:45Â example001 $Â chmodÂ 0764Â example001 $Â lsÂ -lÂ example001 -rwxrw-r--.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 0Â SepÂ 26Â 11:45Â example001 $Â chmodÂ 0640Â example001 $Â lsÂ -lÂ example001 -rw-r-----.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 0Â SepÂ 26Â 11:45Â example001

searchDocs.title: Recursively Setting Permissionsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: It is sometimes useful to use the chmod -R option to recursively set all the permissions on a directory and all of its contents. However, it is quite common to need to set execute permissions on directories but not on files. You can indicate this to chmod using a capital X for the execute permission.  #Â Don'tÂ doÂ this!Â ItÂ willÂ setÂ ExecuteÂ permissionÂ onÂ filesÂ andÂ directories. chmodÂ -RÂ go+rxÂ publicdir #Â Instead,Â doÂ this toÂ setÂ ExecuteÂ permissionÂ onÂ directoriesÂ only (notÂ files): #Â (NoticeÂ theÂ capitalÂ XÂ inÂ theÂ symbolicÂ permissions) chmodÂ -RÂ go+rXÂ publicdir

searchDocs.title: Controlling Permissions on New Files and Directoriesâ€‹
searchDocs.content: There is a setting known as umask which controls the permissions assigned to new files and directories. The umask value is a numeric mode which represents the permissions which are not permitted on new files.  The actual permission which is given to new files is a combination of two values:  -Â TheÂ modeÂ requestedÂ byÂ theÂ softwareÂ creatingÂ theÂ file (usingÂ theÂ open,Â openat,Â orÂ creatÂ systemÂ calls), exceptÂ for  -Â TheÂ modesÂ prohibitedÂ byÂ theÂ umaskÂ value.  For example, a umask value of 0022 represents the permissions----w--w- (write permission for group and other). Therefore, any new files or directories will be created without these permissions. This is the default permission on Matrix.  The umask value can be viewed or set with the umask command.  For example, the touch command requests 0666 (rw-rw-rw-) permission on new files. Here is a demo of how the umask value can change the assigned permissions:  $Â umask #Â viewÂ theÂ currentÂ umask 0022 $Â touchÂ testfile0022 #Â umaskÂ ofÂ 0022Â willÂ denyÂ writeÂ forÂ groupÂ andÂ other $Â lsÂ -lÂ testfile0022 -rw-r--r--.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 0Â SepÂ 26Â 11:54Â testfile0022 $Â umaskÂ 0000 #Â umaskÂ ofÂ 0000Â willÂ notÂ denyÂ anyÂ permissions $Â touchÂ testfile0000 $Â lsÂ -lÂ testfile0000 -rw-rw-rw-.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 0Â SepÂ 26Â 11:54Â testfile0000 $Â umaskÂ 0027 #Â denyÂ groupÂ write,Â plusÂ allÂ permissionsÂ forÂ other $Â touchÂ testfile0027 $Â lsÂ -lÂ testfile0027 -rw-r-----.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 0Â SepÂ 26Â 11:55Â testfile0027   To ensure that no one else has any access to new files and directories that you create on Matrix (unless you change the permission mode of the file after it is created), set your umask to 0077: umask 0077  Note that the umask value is specific to the process that is currently running, and it inherited by child processes. That means that if you're using multiple shells (perhaps in multiple windows), each shell's umask value is specific to that shell, and changing it will not affect the other active shells. However, any command or program that you run from that shell will inherit the umask value. You can set the default umask value for all future bash sessions by placing a umask command into your~/.bashrc file.  Warning: be extremely careful editing your~/.bashrc file, since an error may prevent you from logging in to your Matrix account. Always stay logged in to Matrix on one terminal while using a second terminal to confirm that you are able to successfully log in to the system. If you are not able to login, fix the problem using the first terminal and then re-test.

searchDocs.title: Special Permissionsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: (Note that this is an advanced topic - these permissions are not used on the majority of files).  There are three additional, "special" permissions:  SetÂ UserÂ IDÂ (SUID)Â -Â whenÂ appliedÂ toÂ anÂ executableÂ programÂ file,Â this permissionÂ changesÂ theÂ effectiveÂ userÂ IDÂ fromÂ theÂ userÂ executingÂ the fileÂ toÂ theÂ ownerÂ ofÂ theÂ fileÂ forÂ theÂ durationÂ ofÂ theÂ process.Â ForÂ example, ifÂ aÂ userÂ *jdoe*Â executesÂ theÂ *passwd*Â commandÂ (whichÂ isÂ ownedÂ by theÂ *root*Â userÂ andÂ hasÂ theÂ SetÂ UserÂ IDÂ permissionÂ enabled),Â the effectiveÂ userÂ IDÂ isÂ temporarilyÂ changedÂ toÂ *root*Â whileÂ that commandÂ isÂ executing.Â ThisÂ enablesÂ theÂ *passwd*Â commandÂ toÂ change theÂ user'sÂ passwordÂ inÂ theÂ */etc/shadow*Â file,Â whichÂ theyÂ otherwise doÂ notÂ haveÂ accessÂ to.  SetÂ GroupÂ IDÂ (SGID)Â -Â whenÂ appliedÂ toÂ anÂ executableÂ programÂ file,Â this permissionÂ isÂ similarÂ toÂ SUID,Â butÂ itÂ changesÂ theÂ effectiveÂ groupÂ ID insteadÂ ofÂ theÂ effectiveÂ userÂ ID.Â WhenÂ appliedÂ toÂ aÂ directory,Â this causesÂ allÂ newly-createdÂ filesÂ andÂ directoriesÂ withÂ thatÂ directoryÂ to beÂ ownedÂ byÂ theÂ sameÂ groupÂ thatÂ ownsÂ theÂ directory.Â ForÂ example,Â ifÂ the directoryÂ */var/www/html/*Â isÂ ownedÂ byÂ theÂ groupÂ *website*,Â then anyÂ fileÂ orÂ directoryÂ createdÂ withinÂ */var/www/html/*Â willÂ automatically beÂ ownedÂ byÂ theÂ groupÂ *website*Â insteadÂ ofÂ theÂ groupÂ ofÂ theÂ person creatingÂ theÂ file.  StickyÂ bitÂ (t)Â -Â whenÂ appliedÂ toÂ aÂ directory,Â anyÂ fileÂ withinÂ thatÂ directory mayÂ beÂ renamedÂ orÂ deletedÂ onlyÂ byÂ theÂ ownerÂ ofÂ theÂ file,Â byÂ theÂ ownerÂ ofÂ the directory,Â orÂ byÂ aÂ privilegedÂ processÂ (forÂ example,Â *root*,Â theÂ master systemÂ administrator),Â regardlessÂ ofÂ anyÂ otherÂ permissionsÂ thatÂ mightÂ beÂ set. TheÂ system'sÂ temporaryÂ directoriersÂ (*/tmp*Â andÂ */var/tmp*)Â haveÂ this turnedÂ on.  These permissions are represented in the ls -l output as modifications of the 'x' character:  SUIDÂ changesÂ theÂ user\'sÂ xÂ characterÂ toÂ anÂ sÂ (orÂ SÂ ifÂ eXecuteÂ isÂ notÂ turnedÂ on) SGIDÂ changesÂ theÂ group\'sÂ xÂ characterÂ toÂ anÂ sÂ (orÂ SÂ ifÂ eXecuteÂ isÂ notÂ turnedÂ on) TheÂ stickyÂ bitÂ changesÂ other\'sÂ xÂ characterÂ toÂ aÂ t (orÂ TÂ ifÂ theÂ eXecuteÂ isÂ notÂ turnedÂ on)   When using symbolic modes with chmod, the permissions are requested as follows:  -Â SUIDÂ isÂ "s"Â permissionÂ inÂ theÂ "u"Â community  -Â SGIDÂ isÂ "s"Â permissionÂ inÂ theÂ "g"Â community  -Â StickyÂ isÂ "t"Â permissionÂ inÂ theÂ "o"Â community  When using numeric modes with chmod, these special permissions are represented as an additional octal digit to the left of the three basic octal permission digits. The value of these special permissions is:  4Â SUID 2Â SGID 1Â Sticky   Examples:  $Â cpÂ /usr/bin/cpÂ mycp #Â makeÂ aÂ privateÂ copyÂ ofÂ theÂ 'cp'Â command $Â lsÂ -lÂ mycp #Â viewÂ theÂ originalÂ permissions -rwxr-xr-x.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 145488Â SepÂ 26Â 12:21Â mycp $Â chmodÂ u+sÂ mycp #Â addÂ SUID $Â lsÂ -lÂ mycp #Â viewÂ theÂ newÂ permissions -rwsr-xr-x.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 145488Â SepÂ 26Â 12:21Â mycp $Â cpÂ /usr/bin/mvÂ mymv #Â makeÂ aÂ privateÂ copyÂ ofÂ theÂ 'mv'Â command $Â lsÂ -lÂ mymv #Â viewÂ theÂ originalÂ permissions -rwxr-xr-x.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 137280Â SepÂ 26Â 12:21Â mymv $Â chmodÂ 06755Â mymv #Â turnÂ onÂ SUIDÂ andÂ SGIDÂ andÂ setÂ permissionsÂ toÂ rwxr-xr-x $Â lsÂ -lÂ mymv #Â viewÂ theÂ newÂ permissions -rwsr-sr-x.Â 1Â chrisÂ chrisÂ 137280Â SepÂ 26Â 12:21Â mymv $Â lsÂ -lÂ -dÂ /usr/bin/passwdÂ /tmp #Â viewÂ someÂ existingÂ filesÂ withÂ specialÂ permissions drwxrwxrwt.Â 26Â rootÂ root 600Â SepÂ 26Â 12:21Â /tmp -rwsr-xr-x. 1Â rootÂ rootÂ 32760Â JanÂ 18 2023Â /usr/bin/passwd

searchDocs.title: Securing Your Accountâ€‹
searchDocs.content: There are two ways to secure your account on Matrix:  1. If you do not want to share any of your files with other users, you can disable access to your home directory by turning off all permissions for the group and other communities. The command chmod go= ~ will set this. Since this turns off access permission to that directory, other users will not be able to access any of the files within your home directory, regardless of the permission on the individual file.  2. If you want to share access to some of your files with other users, turn on the appropriate permissions for group and/or other users, and use the umask to limit the permissions on new files and directories.  For example, you might:  1.Â StartÂ byÂ turningÂ offÂ allÂ permissionsÂ onÂ theÂ filesÂ andÂ directoriesÂ thatÂ are currentlyÂ inÂ yourÂ homeÂ directory:  chmodÂ -rÂ go=Â ~/*   2.Â CreateÂ aÂ directoryÂ ofÂ filesÂ youÂ wishÂ toÂ share,Â calledÂ *~/public*.Â Set theÂ permissionÂ onÂ thisÂ directoryÂ soÂ thatÂ groupÂ andÂ othersÂ canÂ accessÂ it:  mkdirÂ ~/public chmodÂ go=rxÂ ~/public   3.Â PlaceÂ anyÂ filesÂ thatÂ youÂ wantÂ toÂ shareÂ inÂ theÂ *~/public*Â directoryÂ and setÂ appropriateÂ permissions:  cpÂ anyFilesYouWantToShareÂ ~/public chmodÂ go=rÂ ~/public   4.Â SetÂ upÂ youÂ umaskÂ soÂ that,Â byÂ default,Â otherÂ usersÂ haveÂ noÂ accessÂ toÂ anyÂ new filesÂ youÂ createÂ (placeÂ thisÂ inÂ yourÂ *~/.bashrc*Â fileÂ toÂ ensureÂ thatÂ itÂ is appliedÂ toÂ allÂ newÂ bashÂ shellsÂ thatÂ youÂ startÂ inÂ theÂ future):  umaskÂ 0077   5.Â EnsureÂ thatÂ usersÂ canÂ accessÂ yourÂ ~/publicÂ directoryÂ throughÂ your homeÂ directory:  chmodÂ go=rxÂ ~`\

searchDocs.title: Windows findstr and Regular Expressions
searchDocs.content: Windows findstr and Regular Expressions The Windows findstr command accepts regular expressions or literal expressions. It will guess what you're using, and may guess incorrectly, so it's best to use the /R and /L options to directly specify if your search pattern is a regexp or literal. Findstr permits multiple search patterns in a quoted string, separated by a space; this acts like a type of alternation. However, this makes it impossible to use a literal space in a search pattern. If you wish to include a space in your search pattern, prepend /C: to your search string. You can use multiple /C: search strings. For example, FINDSTR /R /C:\"red\" /C:\"blue\" INPUTFILE is roughly equivalent to grep -E \"red\|blue\" INPUTFILE Findstr is also limited to (approximately) 127 characters in the regular expression. For information on findstr's regular expression dialect, seehelp findstr. In particular, the findstr command does not support alternation with the | symbol, repetition other than with the *symbol, named character classes [[:*name*:]], or grouping ( ).

searchDocs.title: Processesâ€‹
searchDocs.content: On a multitasking computer system, a process is a single instance of an executing computer program. For example, ssh is one program. If there are no running instances of ssh on a computer system, then there are no ssh processes. If one user starts one ssh session, then one there is one ssh process. If five users start a combined total of twelve ssh sessions, then there are twelve ssh processes.  Each process is assigned a Process ID (PID) and is allocated its own resources, such as memory. Processes are scheduled to run (execute) on a CPU core for a fraction of a second, and then the operating system may intervene and switch the CPU core to run another processes. However, if a process is waiting for an I/O resources, such as data from a storage device, a packet of data from the network, or a keystroke from the user, it may inform the operating system that it does not need to be executed until that resource is available. A process which is ineligible for execution because it is waiting for a resources is called a sleepingprocess.

searchDocs.title: Resource Conflictsâ€‹
searchDocs.content: When the resource requirements of running computer programs significantly exceed available resources, system performance will become unsatisfactory.  It is important to be able to identify the resource consumption of each process, and each operating system provides multiple tools to do this. They also provide tools to terminate processes if they are unstable or consuming excessive resources.

searchDocs.title: Memoryâ€‹
searchDocs.content: On contemporary computer systems, memory is very actively and dynamically managed by the Operating System using the hardware's virtual memory features. This enables many useful techniques, including:  DemandÂ LoadingÂ -Â OnlyÂ theÂ portionÂ ofÂ programsÂ whichÂ areÂ usedÂ areÂ loaded. CodeÂ forÂ featuresÂ thatÂ areÂ notÂ usedÂ isÂ notÂ loadedÂ intoÂ memory.Â ForÂ example, inÂ aÂ wordÂ processorÂ (suchÂ asÂ LibreOffice/OpenOfficeÂ orÂ Word),Â featuresÂ such asÂ tableÂ ofÂ contentÂ generation,Â endnotes,Â andÂ watermarksÂ areÂ notÂ usedÂ in manyÂ documents,Â andÂ theÂ codeÂ forÂ thoseÂ featuresÂ willÂ notÂ beÂ loadedÂ inÂ many cases.SharingÂ ofÂ MemoryÂ -Â SharedÂ librariesÂ (alsoÂ calledÂ DynamicallyÂ Linked Libraries)Â mayÂ beÂ usedÂ byÂ manyÂ differentÂ processes.Â TheseÂ librariesÂ are loadedÂ intoÂ memoryÂ onlyÂ once,Â usingÂ demandÂ loading,Â regardlessÂ ofÂ the numberÂ ofÂ processesÂ usingÂ eachÂ library.Â Similarly,Â aÂ programÂ whichÂ is runningÂ inÂ twoÂ orÂ moreÂ processesÂ willÂ beÂ loadedÂ intoÂ memoryÂ onlyÂ once, andÂ sharedÂ betweenÂ theÂ processes.Â ThisÂ significantlyÂ reducesÂ memory requirements.SwapÂ -Â WhenÂ systemÂ memoryÂ (RAM)Â isÂ approachingÂ fullÂ utilization, theÂ operatingÂ systemÂ mayÂ takeÂ someÂ ofÂ theÂ least-recently-usedÂ areasÂ of memoryÂ andÂ placeÂ themÂ inÂ storageÂ (hardÂ diskÂ orÂ solidÂ stateÂ disk)Â orÂ compress themÂ inÂ orderÂ toÂ avoidÂ runningÂ outÂ ofÂ freeÂ memory.Â AreasÂ ofÂ memoryÂ swapped outÂ mayÂ beÂ swappedÂ backÂ inÂ ifÂ theyÂ areÂ laterÂ required.  Due to the utilization of these techniques and others, the memory consumption of a program can be calculated in many different ways. For example:  YouÂ couldÂ addÂ upÂ theÂ fullÂ sizeÂ ofÂ theÂ program,Â allÂ ofÂ theÂ sharedÂ libraries,Â andÂ theÂ dataÂ usedÂ byÂ aÂ process,Â butÂ thatÂ wouldÂ yieldÂ aÂ largeÂ numberÂ (aÂ pessimisticÂ viewÂ ofÂ memoryÂ consumption).Â TheÂ processÂ isÂ likelyÂ notÂ occupyingÂ thatÂ muchÂ memory,Â andÂ terminatingÂ theÂ processÂ willÂ typicallyÂ releaseÂ onlyÂ aÂ fractionÂ ofÂ thatÂ memoryÂ becauseÂ mostÂ ofÂ theÂ sharedÂ librariesÂ willÂ stillÂ beÂ loadedÂ intoÂ memoryÂ andÂ inÂ useÂ byÂ otherÂ programs.YouÂ couldÂ addÂ upÂ justÂ theÂ portionÂ ofÂ theÂ programÂ inÂ memoryÂ plusÂ theÂ dataÂ areaÂ inÂ memoryÂ usedÂ byÂ aÂ process,Â butÂ thisÂ wouldÂ understateÂ theÂ fullÂ memoryÂ utilizationÂ becauseÂ itÂ doesÂ notÂ includeÂ theÂ sharedÂ librariesÂ norÂ theÂ portionÂ ofÂ theÂ programÂ orÂ dataÂ whichÂ hasÂ beenÂ swappedÂ outÂ orÂ whichÂ hasÂ notÂ (yet)Â beenÂ demand-loaded.  Therefore resource monitoring tools may present several different statistics about memory usage for each process, or may try to present a rough approximation of the amount of total system memory which can be reasonably attributed to a process.

searchDocs.title: CPUâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Each CPU core is independently capable of executing programs. Most modern CPUs have multiple cores (Symmetric Multi Processing, SMP), enabling multiple programs to be executed simultaneously. Many modern CPUs can execute more than one thread on a core (Symmetric Multi Threading, SMT), meaning that they have hardware support for rapid switching between two or more processes (or, in some cases, sub-processes called threads) on one core -- so a 4-core CPU may be marketed as capable of running up to 8 tasks. However, this does not mean that 8 programs can be fully executed at once!  To use an analogy, a SMP processor is a bit like an apartment building, where each core is like an apartment and can fully accommodate a family (whether a single, couple, roommates, or parents and children), or, in the case of the CPU, fully execute a process. SMT capability is a bit like Airbnb rentals, which enable those units to be shared out quickly when they're not in use by the main occupants, or in the case of the CPU, quickly run other threads when the core (or part of the core) is not in use.  Further complicating the issue is the fact that CPUs may have multiple cores of different specifications -- some fast, power-hungry cores used for heavy tasks, and other slower, energy-efficient cores for lighter tasks. Cores may be shut down and started up by the OS as needed. For example, some Seneca lab computers have an Intel CPU with 12 cores consisting of 10 performance cores (capable of running 2 threads) and 2 efficiency cores (capable of running 1 thread). In a similar way, a Google Pixel 8 phone has 4 energy-efficient/low-performance Arm Cortex-A510 cores, 4 mid-range Cortex-A715 cores, and one high-energy-usage/very high-performance Cortex-X3 core.  In addition, current CPUs can operate at a range of speeds, and the OS and hardware work together to dynamically tune the speed to balance temperature, energy usage, and performance.  Therefore, statistics reporting the percentage of CPU capability in use by a process may report the percentage of a core's capability in use, either with or without considering SMT capabilities, or they may report the percentage of the full CPU's capability (including all cores). When cores of different specifications are part of a single CPU, it may be difficult to determine the relative ratio of performance between the different types of cores, especially as the speed of those cores is being adjusted -- and therefore utilization percentages are almost always a rough approximation.

searchDocs.title: Monitoring and Terminating Processes on Windowsâ€‹
Graphical User Interfaceâ€‹
searchDocs.content: To manage processes graphically on Windows, use the Task Managertool. You can access this from the Start menu, or by pressing Ctrl-Alt-Delete and selecting Task Manager from the menu that appears.  The Task Manager display shows processes grouped by executable name, along with approximate resource usage.  To terminate a process, select it using the mouse, and then click on the End Task button in the lower-right corner of the display.

searchDocs.title: Command Line Interface using the CMD Shellâ€‹
searchDocs.content: To manage processes using the CMD shell (the default shell on Windows), use these commands:  1. **tasklist** - displays a list of tasks (processes) active on the system. You can use options to select which processes are displayed, as well as the output format (table, list, or comma-separated values).  2. **taskkill** - terminates a process. By default, this command attempts to get tasks to terminate in a safe manner (for example, if the program is saving a file, that operation will be completed before the program terminates). If a program does not respond to request, you can specify the /f option, which forcibly terminates the program.  You can specify the process to be terminated in one of two ways:  * ByÂ processÂ ID,Â usingÂ theÂ */PID nnn*Â option,Â whichÂ willÂ terminateÂ theÂ processÂ withÂ theÂ specifiedÂ processÂ ID. * ByÂ imageÂ (programÂ orÂ library)Â name,Â usingÂ theÂ */IM name*Â option,Â whichÂ terminatesÂ processesÂ withÂ theÂ givenÂ imageÂ name.Â AsteriskÂ wildcardÂ charactersÂ mayÂ beÂ specifiedÂ asÂ partÂ ofÂ theÂ name.Â NamesÂ mustÂ includeÂ theÂ extensionÂ (forÂ example,Â useÂ *taskkill /im firefox.exe*Â orÂ *taskkill /im firefox**Â insteadÂ ofÂ *taskkill /im firefox*).Â   The tasklist and taskkill commands also provide a mechanism for filtering the process selection; see the online documentation for details (help tasklist or help taskkill).

searchDocs.title: Command Line Interface using Powershellâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Powershell is an alternate Windows shell. You can use these commands to view and terminate processes using Powershell:  1. **get-process** - Displays a list of current processes with basic information about each. You can specify a program name as a positional argument (without the filename extension); see the online documentation for other available options.  2. **stop-process** - Terminates a process. You may specify a PID using the -ID option (stop-process -id pid) or a program name (without the filename extension) using the -NAME option (stop-process -name name).  Tip - Short Names:** Many Powershell commandlets (built-in commands) have short names. The short name for the get-processcommand is ps and the short name for the stop-processcommand is kill, which conveniently match the names of similar commands on Linux!

searchDocs.title: Monitoring and Terminating Processes on Linuxâ€‹
Command Line Interfaceâ€‹
searchDocs.content: From the bash (default shell) command line on Linux, you can view the current process table using the process status command ps. By default, it will show only processes associated with the current shell, and will show only the process ID (PID), terminal, total execution time, and command name:   $Â ps PIDÂ TTY TIMEÂ CMD 303632Â pts/4 00:00:00Â bash 303771Â pts/4 00:00:00Â ps   There are many ps options available to control which processes are displayed and what information is displayed about each process. These are the more commonly-used:   -uÂ user -Â DisplaysÂ allÂ processesÂ ownedÂ byÂ user -e -Â ShowsÂ everyÂ process -l -Â ShowsÂ longÂ output,Â includingÂ processÂ statusÂ (S),Â processÂ IDÂ (PID),Â parentÂ processÂ IDÂ (PPID),Â approximateÂ memoryÂ sizeÂ (SZ),Â totalÂ executionÂ timeÂ (TIME),Â andÂ programÂ nameÂ (CMD) -f -Â ShowsÂ fullÂ output,Â includingÂ processÂ IDÂ (PID),Â parentÂ processÂ IDÂ (PPID),Â processÂ startÂ timeÂ (STIME),Â totalÂ executionÂ timeÂ (TIME),Â andÂ programÂ nameÂ (CMD)   To terminate a process on Linux, send it a signal using the killcommand. Processes are specified by ID:   killÂ PID   By default, processes are send the terminate signal (signal 15, SIGTERM). This requests that the process terminate gracefully (for example, by completing pending operations before stopping). If a program does not respond to this signal, the kill signal (signal 9, SIGKILL) may be specified; this signal tells the operating system to abruptly and forcefully terminate the process. Either of these forms is accepted:   killÂ -9Â PID killÂ -KILLÂ PID   There are many other signals that may be sent to processes; to see a list of all available signals, run the command kill -l or see the online documentation for signal(7) (by running the command: man 7 signal).  To find all processes associated with a given program, use the pgrep command: pgrep name  To terminate processes by program name, use the killall command:killall name
